import Mathlib

/- p1. Is there any natural number n such that $n^2 + 5n + 1$ is divisible by $49$ ? Explain.


p2. It is known that the parabola $y = ax^2 + bx + c$ passes through the points $(-3,4)$ and $(3,16)$, and does not
cut the $x$-axis. Find all possible abscissa values ​​for the vertex point of the parabola.


p3. It is known that $T.ABC$ is a regular triangular pyramid with side lengths of $2$ cm. The points $P, Q, R$, and $S$ are the centroids of triangles $ABC$, $TAB$, $TBC$ and $TCA$, respectively . Determine the volume of the triangular pyramid $P.QRS$ .


p4. At an event invited $13$ special guests consisting of $ 8$ people men and $5$ women. Especially for all those special guests provided $13$ seats in a special row. If it is not expected two women sitting next to each other, determine the number of sitting positions possible for all those special guests.


p5. A table of size $n$ rows and $n$ columns will be filled with numbers $ 1$ or $-1$ so that the product of all the numbers in each row and the product of all the numbers in each column is $-1$. How many different ways to fill the table? -/
theorem other_68425 :
    ∃ n : ℕ, 49 ∣ n^2 + 5 * n + 1 := by

soln_description:
Solution. Let $\frac{x-2}{x+1}=z$, then $x=\frac{z+2}{1-z}, \quad(z \neq 1, z \neq 0)$ and

$$
f\left(\frac{1}{z}\right)+2 f(z)=\frac{z+2}{1-z}
$$

Replacing $z$ with $\frac{1}{z}$, we get:

$$
f(z)+2 f\left(\frac{1}{z}\right)=\frac{1+2 z}{z-1}
$$

From equations (3) and (4), we find $f(z): f(z)=\frac{4 z+5}{3(1-z)}$

and accordingly $f(x)=\frac{4 x+5}{3(1-x)}$.

This is the solution to the given equation.
informal_statement:
## Example 2. Solve the equation

$$
f\left(\frac{x+1}{x-2}\right)+2 f\left(\frac{x-2}{x+1}\right)=x
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- ## Example 2. Solve the equation

$$
f\left(\frac{x+1}{x-2}\right)+2 f\left(\frac{x-2}{x+1}\right)=x
$$ -/
theorem algebra_193306 {f : ℝ → ℝ} (hf : ∀ x, x ≠ 2 → f ((x + 1) / (x - 2)) + 2 * f ((x - 2) / (x + 1)) = x) :
    ∀ x, x ≠ 1 → f x = (4 * x + 5) / (3 * (1 - x)) := by

soln_description:
Solution (1)
$$\begin{aligned}
& (x+y+z)^{3}-27 x y z \\
= & x^{3}+y^{3}+z^{3}+3\left(x^{2} y+y^{2} z+z^{2} x\right)+3\left(x y^{2}+y z^{2}+z x^{2}\right)+6 x y z \\
& -27 x y z \\
= & (x+y+z)\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}-x y-y z-z x\right)+3\left(x^{2} y+y^{2} z+\right. \\
& \left.z^{2} x+x y^{2}+y z^{2}+z x^{2}-6 x y z\right) \\
& =\frac{x+y+z}{2}\left[(x-y)^{2}+(y-z)^{2}+(z-x)^{2}\right]+3\left[x(y-z)^{2}+\right. \\
& \left.y(z-x)^{2}+z(x-y)^{2}\right] .
\end{aligned}$$

Assume without loss of generality that $x \geqslant y \geqslant z$, then $z \geqslant 1, y \geqslant 1, x \geqslant 2$.
Thus,
$$\begin{aligned}
& (x+y+z)^{3}-27 x y z \\
\geqslant & \frac{1+1+2}{2} \cdot\left[(x-y)^{2}+(y-z)^{2}+(z-x)^{2}\right]+3\left[(y-z)^{2}+\right. \\
& \left.(z-x)^{2}+(x-y)^{2}\right] \\
= & 5 \cdot\left[(x-y)^{2}+(y-z)^{2}+(z-x)^{2}\right] \\
\geqslant & 10
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, $(x+y+z)^{3}-27 x y z \geqslant 10$, and equality holds when $(x, y, z)=(2,1,1)$.
(2) Assume without loss of generality that $x>y>z$, then $z \geqslant 1, y \geqslant 2, x \geqslant 3$.
From part (1),
$$\begin{aligned}
(x+y+z)^{3}-27 x y z \geqslant & \frac{6}{2} \cdot\left[(x-y)^{2}+(y-z)^{2}+(z-x)^{2}\right]+3 \cdot[3(y \\
& \left.-z)^{2}+2(z-x)^{2}+(x-y)^{2}\right] \\
\geqslant & 3 \cdot\left(1^{2}+1^{2}+2^{2}\right)+3 \cdot\left(3 \cdot 1^{2}+2 \cdot 2^{2}+1^{2}\right) \\
& =54
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, $(x+y+z)^{3}-27 x y z \geqslant 54$, and equality holds when $(x, y, z)=(3,2,1)$. Note that part (1) is equivalent to the following proposition:
For distinct positive integers $a, b, c$, we have
$$\frac{a+b+c}{3} \geqslant \sqrt[3]{a b c+\frac{10}{27}}$$

Of course, (1) can also be proven using the following method (incremental substitution):
Proof Assume without loss of generality that $1 \leqslant a \leqslant b \leqslant c, b=a+x, c=a+y$. Then $x, y \geqslant 0$, and $x, y$ are not both $0 (x \leqslant y)$.

At this point, (1) is equivalent to proving:
$$9 a\left(x^{2}-x y+y^{2}\right)+(x+y)^{3} \geqslant 10$$

Since $a \geqslant 1, x^{2}-x y+y^{2} \geqslant 1, x+y \geqslant 1$, the above inequality clearly holds, and equality is achieved when $a=1, x^{2}-x y+y^{2}=1, x+y=1$, i.e., $(a, x, y)=(1,0,1)$.
informal_statement:
Example 7 (1) If $x, y, z$ are positive integers not all equal, find the minimum value of $(x+y+z)^{3}-27 x y z$;
(2) If $x, y, z$ are positive integers all different, find the minimum value of $(x+y+z)^{3}-27 x y z$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 7 (1) If $x, y, z$ are positive integers not all equal, find the minimum value of $(x+y+z)^{3}-27 x y z$;
(2) If $x, y, z$ are positive integers all different, find the minimum value of $(x+y+z)^{3}-27 x y z$. -/
theorem algebra_601215 :
    IsLeast {n : ℤ | ∃ x y z : ℕ, x > 0 ∧ y > 0 ∧ z > 0 ∧ n = (x + y + z)^3 - 27 * x * y * z ∧ ¬(x = y ∧ y = z)} 54 ∧
    IsLeast {n : ℤ | ∃ x y z : ℕ, x > 0 ∧ y > 0 ∧ z > 0 ∧ n = (x + y + z)^3 - 27 * x * y * z ∧ x ≠ y ∧ y ≠ z ∧ x ≠ z} 54 := by

soln_description:
# Solution.

Domain of definition: $y>0, x \geq 0$.

In the domain of definition, the second equation of the system takes the form: $x=y^{3} \sqrt{x}$.
I. $x=0, y=\sqrt[3]{1-\frac{1}{a}}=\sqrt[3]{\frac{a-1}{a}}>0 \Leftrightarrow\left[\begin{array}{l}a1\end{array}\right.$

II. $x>0, y=\sqrt{x} ;(\sqrt{x}-1)(\sqrt{x}+1)=a(\sqrt{x}-1)$.

1) $\sqrt{x}=1, x=1, y=1, a \in R$.
2) $\sqrt{x}+1=a, \sqrt{x}=a-1>0, a>1$. The solution found $x=(a-1)^{2}, y=\sqrt[3]{a-1}$ coincides with the previous one if $1=a-1, a=2$. Thus, for $a \in(1 ; 2) \cup(2 ;+\infty) x=(a-1)^{2}, y=$ $\sqrt[3]{a-1}$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_06_d45ee4ec72eb6c7fb975g-4.jpg?height=226&width=1468&top_left_y=207&top_left_x=320)

Answer:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& a \in(-\infty ; 0) \cup\{2\}, x_{1}=0, y_{1}=1-\frac{1}{a} ; x_{2}=1, y_{2}=1 \\
& a \in[0 ; 1], x=1, y=1 ; \\
& a \in(1 ; 2) \cup(2 ;+\infty), x_{1}=0, y_{1}=\sqrt[3]{1-\frac{1}{a}} ; x_{2}=1, y_{2}=1 ; x_{3}=(a-1)^{2}, y_{3}=\sqrt[3]{a-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

4b. Find the perimeter of the figure common to both pyramids (see the condition of problem 4a).

(8 points)

## Solution.

Lines $A C$ and $E F$ are parallel, $A C F E$ is a parallelogram, the figure common to both pyramids is the triangle $A G E$, where point $G$ is the intersection of the diagonals of the parallelogram $A C F E$. The figure common to both pyramids is the triangle $A G E$.

$$
\begin{gathered}
G E=C E / 2 . C E=\sqrt{C K^{2}+K E^{2}}=\sqrt{20^{2}+20^{2}}=20 \sqrt{2}, G E=10 \sqrt{2} \\
A F=\sqrt{40^{2}+40^{2}+20^{2}}=60, \quad A G=A F / 2=30 \\
A E=\sqrt{20^{2}+10^{2}+20^{2}}=30 \\
P_{A G E}=10 \sqrt{2}+60
\end{gathered}
$$

Answer: $10 \sqrt{2}+60$.

## Solution to Variant №3 (Mathematics - 10th Grade)
informal_statement:
3. Specify all values of $a$ for which the system of equations $\left\{\begin{array}{c}x-1=a\left(y^{3}-1\right) \\ \frac{2 x}{\left|y^{3}\right|+y^{3}}=\sqrt{x}\end{array}\right.$ has at least one solution, and solve it for each $a$.

#
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 3. Specify all values of $a$ for which the system of equations $\left\{\begin{array}{c}x-1=a\left(y^{3}-1\right) \\ \frac{2 x}{\left|y^{3}\right|+y^{3}}=\sqrt{x}\end{array}\right.$ has at least one solution, and solve it for each $a$.

# -/
theorem algebra_229078 (a : ℝ) :
    ∃ x y, x - 1 = a * (y ^ 3 - 1) ∧ 2 * x / (|y ^ 3| + y ^ 3) = Real.sqrt x ↔
    a = 10 * Real.sqrt 2 + 60 := by

informal_statement:
The average of the two positive integers $m$ and $n$ is 5 . What is the largest possible value for $n$ ?
(A) 5
(B) 7
(C) 9
(D) 11
(E) 13
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- The average of the two positive integers $m$ and $n$ is 5 . What is the largest possible value for $n$ ?
(A) 5
(B) 7
(C) 9
(D) 11
(E) 13 -/
theorem algebra_261725 (m n : ℕ) (hm : 0 < m) (hn : 0 < n)
    (h : (m + n) / 2 = 5) :
    n ≤ 9 := by

informal_statement: Let $\sec x + \tan x = \frac{22}{7}$, $\csc x + \cot x = \frac{m}{n}$, (where $m$ and $n$ have no common divisor greater than $1$), then $m+n=$ ___          ___ .
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $\sec x + \tan x = \frac{22}{7}$, $\csc x + \cot x = \frac{m}{n}$, (where $m$ and $n$ have no common divisor greater than $1$), then $m+n=$ ___          ___ . -/
theorem algebra_10649 {x : ℝ} {m n : ℕ} (hm : m > 0) (hn : n > 0)
    (h1 : 1 / Real.cos x + Real.tan x = 22 / 7) (h2 : 1 / Real.sin x + 1 / Real.tan x = m / n)
    (h3 : Nat.Coprime m n) : m + n = 44 := by

informal_statement: Let $p$ and $q$ be prime numbers. If $q \mid 2^p - 1$, prove that there exists a natural number $k$ such that $q = 2kp + 1$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $p$ and $q$ be prime numbers. If $q \mid 2^p - 1$, prove that there exists a natural number $k$ such that $q = 2kp + 1$. -/
theorem number_theory_3444 (p q : ℕ) (hp : p.Prime) (hq : q.Prime)
    (h : q ∣ 2^p - 1) : ∃ k, q = 2 * k * p + 1 := by

soln_description:
Solution: Using the universal substitution method: Let $\operatorname{tg} \frac{x}{2}=t$, then the original equation becomes: $\frac{2 t}{1+t^{2}}+\frac{1-t^{2}}{1+t^{2}}+\frac{2 t}{1-t^{2}}=\frac{1+t^{2}}{1-t^{2}}$. Eliminating the denominators and simplifying, we get $t(t-1)=0$.
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\therefore t_{1}=0, \quad t_{2}=1 . \\
\text { When } t_{1}=0, \text { i.e., } \operatorname{tg} \frac{x}{2}=0, \text { then } x_{1}=2 n \pi ;
\end{array}
$$

When $t_{2}=1$, i.e., $\operatorname{tg} \frac{x}{2}=1$, then $x_{2}=2 n \pi+\frac{\pi}{2}$.
Verification: Since $x=(2 n+1) \pi$ makes $\operatorname{tg} \frac{x}{2}$ undefined, we should consider possible lost roots:
$$
x=(2 n+1) \pi \text {. }
$$

Mark points $A(2 n \pi), B(2 n \pi$
$$
+\frac{\pi}{2} \text { ), } C(2 n \pi+\pi) \text { on the unit circle (Figure 14). }
$$

Comparing with the original equation, it is clear that $x=2 n \pi+\frac{\pi}{2}$ is an extraneous root, which should be discarded. And
$$
x=2 n \pi, \quad x=(2 n+1) \pi
$$

satisfy the original equation, so the solutions to the original equation are:
$$
x=k \pi \text {, ( } k \text { is an integer) }
$$
informal_statement:
Example 7. Solve the equation:
$$
\sin x + \cos x + \tan x = \sec x
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 7. Solve the equation:
$$
\sin x + \cos x + \tan x = \sec x
$$ -/
theorem algebra_316424 (x : ℝ) :
    Real.sin x + Real.cos x + Real.tan x = 1 / Real.cos x ↔ ∃ k : ℤ, x = k * Real.pi := by

soln_description: Solution. $[\sin (2 n+1) A+\sin (2 n+1) B]+\sin (2 n+1)(\pi-(A+B))=$ $=2 \sin \frac{2 n+1}{2}(A+B) \times \cos \frac{2 n+1}{2}(A-B)+2 \sin \frac{2 n+1}{2}(A+B) \cdot \cos \frac{2 n+1}{2}(A+B)=$ $2 \sin \frac{2 n+1}{2}(A+B) \cdot\left(\cos \frac{2 n+1}{2}(A-B)+\cos \frac{2 n+1}{2}(A+B)\right)=4 \sin \frac{2 n+1}{2}(\pi-C) \times$ $\cos \left(\frac{2 n+1}{2} \times A\right) \cdot \cos \left(\frac{2 n+1}{2} B\right)=4 \sin \left(\frac{\pi}{2}+\pi n-\frac{2 n+1}{2} C\right) \cdot \cos \frac{2 n+1}{2} A \cdot \cos \frac{2 n+1}{2} B=$ $=(-1)^{n} \cdot 4 \cos \frac{2 n+1}{2} C \cdot \cos \frac{2 n+1}{2} B \cdot \cos \frac{2 n+1}{2} A$
informal_statement:
3.472 Given: $\boldsymbol{A}, \boldsymbol{B}, \boldsymbol{C}$ - angles of a certain triangle. Prove:

$\sin (2 n+1) A+\sin (2 n+1) B+\sin (2 n+1) C=(-1)^{n} \cdot 4 \cos \frac{2 n+1}{2} A \times$

$\times \cos \frac{2 n+1}{2} B \cdot \cos \frac{2 n+1}{2} C$, where $n-$ is an integer.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped Real

/- 3.472 Given: $\boldsymbol{A}, \boldsymbol{B}, \boldsymbol{C}$ - angles of a certain triangle. Prove:

$\sin (2 n+1) A+\sin (2 n+1) B+\sin (2 n+1) C=(-1)^{n} \cdot 4 \cos \frac{2 n+1}{2} A \times$

$\times \cos \frac{2 n+1}{2} B \cdot \cos \frac{2 n+1}{2} C$, where $n-$ is an integer. -/
theorem algebra_196587 (A B C : Real) (hA : A ∈ Ioo 0 π)
  (hB : B ∈ Ioo 0 π) (hC : C ∈ Ioo 0 π) (hABC : A + B + C = π)
  (n : ℤ) :
  sin ((2 * n + 1) * A) + sin ((2 * n + 1) * B) + sin ((2 * n + 1) * C) =
  (-1) ^ n * 4 * cos ((2 * n + 1) / 2 * A) * cos ((2 * n + 1) / 2 * B) * cos ((2 * n + 1) / 2 * C) := by

soln_description:
## Solution.

Let $V_{1}, V_{2}$ be the speeds of the first and second tourists, respectively, and $x$ be the time it takes for the second tourist to cover the distance that the first tourist covers in 2 hours. According to the problem, we have the system $\left\{\begin{array}{l}x V_{2}=120 V_{1}, \\ V_{2} x+60 V_{2}=120 V_{1}+V_{1}(x+28) .\end{array}\right.$ From the first equation, we express $\frac{V_{1}}{V_{2}}$ and substitute it into the second equation. From the resulting equation, we find $x=72$ (min). Then the first tourist spent a total of $120+72+28=220$ (min) on the entire journey, and the second tourist spent $-60+72=132$ (min).

Answer: 3 hours 40 minutes and 2 hours 12 minutes.
informal_statement: 13.317. One tourist set out at 6 a.m., and the second - towards him at 7 a.m. They met at 8 a.m. and, without stopping, continued their journey. How much time did each of them spend on the entire journey, if the first arrived at the place where the second started 28 minutes later than the second arrived at the place where the first started? It is assumed that each walked without stopping at a constant speed.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 13.317. One tourist set out at 6 a.m., and the second - towards him at 7 a.m. They met at 8 a.m. and, without stopping, continued their journey. How much time did each of them spend on the entire journey, if the first arrived at the place where the second started 28 minutes later than the second arrived at the place where the first started? It is assumed that each walked without stopping at a constant speed. -/
theorem algebra_176917 (d v1 v2 : ℝ) (h₀ : d > 0) (h₁ : v1 > 0) (h₂ : v2 > 0)
    (h₃ : d / v1 = d / v2 + 28 / 60) :
    d / v1 = 3 ∧ d / v2 = 4 := by

soln_description: The number of ways to partition $k$ into the sum of $n$ positive integers is finite, hence the maximum value $F(k)$ exists. If the product is to be maximized, then the difference between any two of the $n$ positive integers must be less than 2. Otherwise, if among the positive integers there are $a$ and $a+s, s \geqslant 2$, then replacing $a, a+s$ with $a+1, a+s-1$ would increase the product, as $a(a+s)<(a+1)(a+s-1)$. Let $k=a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}, a_{1} \leqslant a_{2} \leqslant \cdots \leqslant a_{n}, 0 \leqslant a_{n}-a_{1} \leqslant 1$, then $n a_{1} \leqslant k<n a_{1}+n$, so $a_{1}=\left[\frac{k}{n}\right]=q$. Therefore, when $k=\underbrace{q+q+\cdots+q}_{n \sim \uparrow}+$ $\underbrace{(q+1)+\cdots+(q+1)}$, the product is maximized, i.e., $F(k)=q^{n-r}(q+1)^{r}$.
informal_statement:
14.5.21 ** Given $k, n (k \geqslant n)$ are positive integers. $k$ divided by $n$ gives a quotient $q$ and a remainder $r$. Split $k$ into the sum of $n$ positive integers. For all such partitions, the maximum value of their product is $F(k)$.
Prove: $F(k)=q^{n-r} \cdot(q+1)^{r}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Finset

/- 14.5.21 ** Given $k, n (k \geqslant n)$ are positive integers. $k$ divided by $n$ gives a quotient $q$ and a remainder $r$. Split $k$ into the sum of $n$ positive integers. For all such partitions, the maximum value of their product is $F(k)$.
Prove: $F(k)=q^{n-r} \cdot(q+1)^{r}$. -/
theorem number_theory_289681 {k n : ℕ} (hn : 0 < n) (hk : n ≤ k) :
    IsGreatest {x | ∃ s : Fin n → ℕ, (∀ i, 0 < s i) ∧ (∑ i, s i) = k ∧ x = ∏ i, s i} (k / n ^ (n - (k % n)) * (k / n + 1) ^ (k % n)) := by

soln_description:
9. The function $y=c^{x}$ is monotonically decreasing on $\mathbf{R}$ if and only if $0<c<1$. The solution set of $01$ is $\mathbf{R} \Leftrightarrow y=x+|x-2 c|$ is always greater than 1 on $\mathbf{R}$.
Because $x+|x-2 c|=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}2 x-2 c, & x \geqslant 2 c \\ 2 c, & x<2 c\end{array}\right.$, the minimum value of $x+|x-2 c|$ is $2c$. For $x+|x-2 c|>1$ to hold, we need $2c>1$ which means $c>\frac{1}{2}$. If $p$ is correct and $q$ is not, then $0<c \leqslant \frac{1}{2}$; if $p$ is not correct and $q$ is, then $c \geqslant 1$. Therefore, the range of $c$ is $\left(0, \frac{1}{2}\right] \cup[1,+\infty)$.
informal_statement:
9. Given: $c>0$, let $p$ : the function $y=c^{x}$ is monotonically decreasing on $\mathbf{R}$, $q$ : the solution set of the inequality $x+|x-2 c|>1$ is
R. If $p$ and $q$ are such that exactly one of them is true, find the range of values for $c$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- 9. Given: $c>0$, let $p$ : the function $y=c^{x}$ is monotonically decreasing on $\mathbf{R}$, $q$ : the solution set of the inequality $x+|x-2 c|>1$ is
R. If $p$ and $q$ are such that exactly one of them is true, find the range of values for $c$. -/
theorem algebra_281861 {c : ℝ} (hc : c > 0) :
    ((∀ x y, x < y → c^x > c^y) ∧ ¬(∀ x, x + abs (x - 2 * c) > 1)) ∨
    (¬(∀ x y, x < y → c^x > c^y) ∧ (∀ x, x + abs (x - 2 * c) > 1)) ↔
    c ∈ Ioc 0 (1 / 2) ∪ Ici 1 := by

soln_description: 27. When $p \equiv 3(\bmod 8)$, $\left(\frac{2}{p}\right)=-1.2,4,6, \cdots, p-1$ contains the same number of quadratic residues as the number of quadratic non-residues in $1,2, \cdots,(p-1) / 2$. From this and Exercise 5, Question 12 (iii), we deduce that $R^{(2)}=N_{1}$. When $p \equiv 7(\bmod 8)$, $\left(\frac{2}{p}\right)=1.2,4,6, \cdots, p-1$ contains the same number of quadratic residues as the number of quadratic residues in $1,2, \cdots,(p-1) / 2$. From this and Exercise 5, Question 12 (iii), we get $R^{(2)}=$ ( $p-1) / 2-N_{1}$ (Note: When $p \equiv 1(\bmod 4)$, by the same argument and Exercise 5, Questions 12 (iii), (iv), we know that $\left.R^{(2)}=(p-1) / 4.\right)$.
informal_statement:
27. Let the prime $p \equiv 3(\bmod 4)$, and the number of even quadratic residues among $1,2, \cdots, p-1$ be denoted as $R^{(2)}$. Prove:
$$R^{(2)}=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}
N_{1}, & p \equiv 3(\bmod 8), \\
(p-1) / 2-N_{1}, & p \equiv 7(\bmod 8),
\end{array}\right.$$

where $N_{1}$ is given by Exercise 12 (iii) of §5 5 Exercise Five.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 27. Let the prime $p \equiv 3(\bmod 4)$, and the number of even quadratic residues among $1,2, \cdots, p-1$ be denoted as $R^{(2)}$. Prove:
$$R^{(2)}=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}
N_{1}, & p \equiv 3(\bmod 8), \\
(p-1) / 2-N_{1}, & p \equiv 7(\bmod 8),
\end{array}\right.$$

where $N_{1}$ is given by Exercise 12 (iii) of §5 5 Exercise Five. -/
theorem number_theory_6424 {p : ℕ} (hp : Nat.Prime p) (h : p ≡ 3 [MOD 4]) :
    {x | ∃ y, x = y^2 ∧ Even x ∧ x ∈ Finset.Icc 1 (p - 1)}.ncard =
    if p ≡ 3 [MOD 8] then
      (Nat.card {x | ∃ y, x = y^2 ∧ Even x ∧ x ∈ Finset.Icc 1 (p / 2)}) else
      ((p - 1) / 2 - (Nat.card {x | ∃ y, x = y^2 ∧ Even x ∧ x ∈ Finset.Icc 1 (p / 2)})) := by

informal_statement: Determine the limit $\displaystyle \lim_{n\rightarrow \infty}\frac{\int^{n}_{0}\sin^2 (x)|\cos x| \, dx}{n}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Filter Function

/- Determine the limit $\displaystyle \lim_{n\rightarrow \infty}\frac{\int^{n}_{0}\sin^2 (x)|\cos x| \, dx}{n}$. -/
theorem calculus_5090 :
  Tendsto (λ n => (∫ x in (0)..n, sin x ^ 2 * abs (cos x)) / n) atTop (𝓝 (2 / (3 * Real.pi))) := by

soln_description:
Solution. According to the definition (see formula 2.6.I), we first find the initial moments using formula (2.6.2):

$$
\begin{gathered}
v_{1}=M(X)=1 \cdot 0.4 + 2 \cdot 0.6 = 1.6, \quad(a=1.6) \\
v_{2}=M\left(X^{2}\right)=1^{2} \cdot 0.4 + 2^{2} \cdot 0.6 = 2.8 \\
v_{3}=M\left(X^{3}\right)=1^{3} \cdot 0.4 + 2^{3} \cdot 0.6 = 5.2
\end{gathered}
$$

We will now compute the central moments. It was previously proven that $\mu_{1}=$. і (see example 2, $\left.\mu_{1}=M((X-a))=0\right)$. According to formulas (2.6.12) and (2.6.13):

$$
\begin{gathered}
\mu_{2}=v_{2}-v_{1}^{2}=2.8-(1.6)^{2}=0.24 \\
\mu_{3}=v_{3}-3 v_{1} v_{2}+2 v_{1}^{3}=5.2-3 \cdot 1.6 \cdot 2.8+2 \cdot(1.6)^{3}=-0.48
\end{gathered}
$$

Remark. The values of $\mu_{2}$ and $\mu_{3}$ can also be found directly, according to formulas (2.6.8) and (2.6.9):

$$
\mu_{2}=M(X-a)^{2}=(1-1.6)^{2} \cdot 0.4 + (2-1.6)^{2} \cdot 0.6 = 0.36 \cdot 0.4 + 0.16 \cdot 0.6 = 0.24
$$

$$
\mu_{3}=M(X-a)^{3}=(1-1.6)^{3} \cdot 0.4 + (2-1.6)^{3} \cdot 0.6 = (-0.216) \cdot 0.4 + 0.064 \cdot 0.6 = -0.48
$$
informal_statement:
Example 4. A discrete random variable $X$ is given by the distribution law:

| $X$ | 1 | 2 |
| :---: | :---: | :---: |
| $P$ | 0.4 | 0.6 |

Find the first, second, and third central moments of the random variable $X$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 4. A discrete random variable $X$ is given by the distribution law:

| $X$ | 1 | 2 |
| :---: | :---: | :---: |
| $P$ | 0.4 | 0.6 |

Find the first, second, and third central moments of the random variable $X$. -/
theorem algebra_170217 (X : Fin 2 → ℝ) (hX : X 0 = 1 ∧ X 1 = 2)
    (P : Fin 2 → ℝ) (hP : P 0 = 0.4 ∧ P 1 = 0.6) :
    ∑ i, (X i - (∑ j, X j * P j)) * P i = 0 ∧
    ∑ i, (X i - (∑ j, X j * P j))^2 * P i = 0.24 ∧
    ∑ i, (X i - (∑ j, X j * P j))^3 * P i = -0.48 := by

soln_description:
Solution. $1^{\circ}$. We have $y^{\prime}=1-2 \sin 2 x$.

$2^{0}$. Determine the critical points belonging to the given interval: $1-2 \sin 2 x=0, \sin 2 x=1 / 2, 2 x=\pi / 6, x=\pi / 12$.

$3^{\circ}$. Find $y^{\prime \prime}=-4 \cos 2 x$.

$4^{0}$. Since $y^{\prime \prime}(\pi / 12)=-4 \cos (\pi / 6)=-2 \sqrt{3}<0$, the function has a maximum at $x=\pi / 12$:

$$
y_{\max }=y\left(\frac{\pi}{12}\right)=\frac{\pi}{12}+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \approx 1.13
$$
informal_statement: 588. $y=x+\cos 2x$ in the interval $(0, \pi / 4)$.
informal_proof:
We want to show that there exists a value \( x \) in the open interval \( (0, \pi/4) \) such that for the function \( f(x) = x + \cos(2x) \), we have \( f(x) = \pi/12 + \sqrt{3}/2 \).

The proof proceeds by directly exhibiting such a value of \( x \) and verifying that it satisfies the given conditions.

**Step 1: Choose a candidate value for \( x \)**
Let \( x = \pi/12 \).

**Step 2: Verify that \( x \) is in the interval \( (0, \pi/4) \)**
This requires showing two inequalities: \( 0 < \pi/12 \) and \( \pi/12 < \pi/4 \).
*   To show \( 0 < \pi/12 \): Since \( \pi \) is a positive real number, \( \pi/12 \) is also positive. This is a straightforward arithmetic fact.
*   To show \( \pi/12 < \pi/4 \): This inequality is equivalent to \( 1/12 < 1/4 \), which is true because \( 12 > 4 \). Multiplying both sides by \( \pi \) (which is positive) preserves the inequality.

Thus, \( \pi/12 \in (0, \pi/4) \) is confirmed.

**Step 3: Verify that \( f(x) \) equals the target value \( \pi/12 + \sqrt{3}/2 \)**
Substitute \( x = \pi/12 \) into the function definition \( f(x) = x + \cos(2x) \).
We need to show:
\[ f(\pi/12) = \pi/12 + \cos(2 \cdot \pi/12) = \pi/12 + \sqrt{3}/2 \]
This simplifies to showing that \( \cos(2 \cdot \pi/12) = \sqrt{3}/2 \).

Let's evaluate the argument of the cosine function:
\[ 2 \cdot \pi/12 = \pi/6 \]
So the task reduces to showing \( \cos(\pi/6) = \sqrt{3}/2 \).
This is a standard trigonometric identity. The cosine of \( \pi/6 \) radians (or 30 degrees) is indeed \( \sqrt{3}/2 \).

Therefore, substituting this back into the expression for \( f(\pi/12) \):
\[ f(\pi/12) = \pi/12 + \cos(\pi/6) = \pi/12 + \sqrt{3}/2 \]
This matches the required target value.

Since we have found an \( x \) (namely \( \pi/12 \)) that lies within the interval \( (0, \pi/4) \) and for which \( f(x) \) evaluates to \( \pi/12 + \sqrt{3}/2 \), the existence is proven.

\(\blacksquare\)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- 588. $y=x+\cos 2x$ in the interval $(0, \pi / 4)$. -/
theorem calculus_156138 (f : ℝ → ℝ) (hf : f = λ x => x + cos (2 * x)) :
    ∃ x ∈ Ioo 0 (π / 4), f x = π / 12 + sqrt 3 / 2 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

theorem calculus_156138 (f : ℝ → ℝ) (hf : f = λ x => x + cos (2 * x)) :
    ∃ x ∈ Ioo 0 (π / 4), f x = π / 12 + sqrt 3 / 2 := by
  use π / 12
  constructor
  · -- Show that π/12 is in the interval (0, π/4)
    constructor
    · -- Show π/12 > 0
      linarith [Real.pi_pos]
    · -- Show π/12 < π/4
      linarith [Real.pi_pos]
  · -- Show f(π/12) = π/12 + sqrt(3)/2
    rw [hf]
    have h1 : cos (2 * (π / 12)) = sqrt 3 / 2 := by
      have h2 : 2 * (π / 12) = π / 6 := by ring
      rw [h2]
      have h3 : cos (π / 6) = sqrt 3 / 2 := by
        exact cos_pi_div_six
      rw [h3]
    simp [h1]
    <;> ring_nf <;> field_simp [Real.pi_pos]
    <;> linarith [Real.pi_pos]

informal_statement: Let the function $ f(x)= \frac{x^{2}+x+16}{x}(2 \leqslant x\leqslant a)$, where the real number $a>2$. If the range of $f(x)$ is $[9,11]$, then the range of values for $a$ is ___          ___ .
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- Let the function $ f(x)= \frac{x^{2}+x+16}{x}(2 \leqslant x\leqslant a)$, where the real number $a>2$. If the range of $f(x)$ is $[9,11]$, then the range of values for $a$ is ___          ___ . -/
theorem algebra_13136 {f : ℝ → ℝ} (hf : ∀ x, 2 ≤ x ∧ x ≤ a → f x = (x^2 + x + 16)/x)
  (ha : 2 < a) (h : ∀ x, 2 ≤ x ∧ x ≤ a → f x ∈ Icc 9 11) :
  4 ≤ a ∧ a ≤ 8 := by

soln_description:
3. From the problem, we know that $f(a, b)$ is the square of the distance from point $P\left(a, \sqrt{2-a^{2}}\right)$ on the circle $x^{2}+y^{2}=2$ to point $Q\left(b, \frac{9}{b}\right)$ on the hyperbola $x y=9$. Since $\sqrt{2-a^{2}} \geqslant 0$, point $P$ lies on the upper half of the circle $x^{2}+y^{2}=2(y \geqslant 0)$. It is easy to see that we only need to consider point $Q$ on the part of the curve $x y=9$ in the first quadrant $(x>0, y>0)$.

Let $Q(x, y)$ be any point on the curve $x y=9(x>0)$. It is easy to see that point $P$ should lie on the line connecting the origin $O$ and $Q$. By the triangle inequality, for any other point $P^{\prime}$ on the circle, we have $O P^{\prime}+P^{\prime} Q>O P+P Q, P^{\prime} Q>P Q$, so we can first find the minimum value of $|O Q|$. Since $|O Q|^{2}=x^{2}+y^{2} \geqslant 2 x y=2 \cdot 9=18$, we have $|O Q| \geqslant \sqrt{18}$, with equality if and only if $x=y=3$. Therefore, when point $Q$ is $(3,3)$, $|P Q|$ has a minimum value of $\sqrt{18}-\sqrt{2}$, and $f(a, b)$ has a minimum value of $(\sqrt{18}-\sqrt{2})^{2}=8$. That is, when $a=1, b=3$, $f(a, b)$ has a minimum value of 8.
informal_statement: 3. Find the minimum value of the function $f(a, b)=(a-b)^{2}+\left(\sqrt{2-a^{2}}-\frac{9}{b}\right)^{2}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- 3. Find the minimum value of the function $f(a, b)=(a-b)^{2}+\left(\sqrt{2-a^{2}}-\frac{9}{b}\right)^{2}$. -/
theorem algebra_127792 :
  IsLeast {x : ℝ | ∃ a b, x = (a - b)^2 + (Real.sqrt (2 - a^2) - 9 / b)^2} 8 := by

soln_description:
Answer: 2. (C)

Options.

$$
\begin{array}{|l|l|l|l|l|l|l|l|l|}
\hline \mathbf{A} & 0 & \mathbf{B} & 1 & \mathbf{C} & 2 & \mathbf{D} & 3 & \mathbf{E} \\
4 & \mathbf{F} \\
\hline
\end{array}
$$
informal_statement:
3-2. Calculate the sum

$$
S=\frac{2013}{2 \cdot 6}+\frac{2013}{6 \cdot 10}+\frac{2013}{10 \cdot 14}+\ldots+\frac{2013}{2010 \cdot 2014}
$$

In your answer, specify the remainder when the nearest even number to the obtained value of $S$ is divided by 5.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Finset Real

/- 3-2. Calculate the sum

$$
S=\frac{2013}{2 \cdot 6}+\frac{2013}{6 \cdot 10}+\frac{2013}{10 \cdot 14}+\ldots+\frac{2013}{2010 \cdot 2014}
$$

In your answer, specify the remainder when the nearest even number to the obtained value of $S$ is divided by 5. -/
theorem algebra_191832 : (∑ i ∈ range 503, (2013 / ((4 * i + 2) * (4 * i + 6)))) % 5 = 2 := by

soln_description:
A trade deficit occurs when imports (import) are greater than exports (export). Let $x$ represent the imports and $y$ the exports in 1994 (in billion dollars). Then,

$$
x - y = 3.8
$$

In 1995, exports increased by $11\%$ compared to the previous year, i.e., $1.11 y$, and imports increased by $3\%$, i.e., $1.03 x$, and the deficit is

$$
1.03 x - 1.11 y = 3
$$

Substituting the value $x = 3.8 + y$ from equation (1) into equation (2),

$$
1.03(3.8 + y) - 1.11 y = 3
$$

from which $y = 11.425$ and $x = 15.225$ billion dollars.
informal_statement: In 1994, the trade balance deficit was 3.8 billion dollars. According to the Economic Research Institute RT, assuming an 11% increase in exports and a 3% increase in imports, the trade deficit would decrease to 3 billion dollars in 1995. What was the magnitude of exports and imports in 1994?
informal_proof:
We are given two real numbers \(x\) and \(y\) representing magnitudes, which must be positive (i.e., \(x > 0\) and \(y > 0\)). These numbers satisfy the following system of linear equations:
1.  \( (1 + 3/100)x - (1 + 11/100)y = 3 \)
2.  \( x - y = 3.8 \)

Our goal is to prove that \(x = 15.225\) and \(y = 11.425\).

First, we simplify the coefficients in the first equation and use the second equation to express one variable in terms of the other.

From the second equation, \(x - y = 3.8\), we can isolate \(x\) by adding \(y\) to both sides:
\[ x = y + 3.8 \quad (*)\ \]

Next, we substitute this expression for \(x\) into the first equation. We also simplify the numerical coefficients: \(1 + 3/100 = 1.03\) and \(1 + 11/100 = 1.11\). The first equation then becomes:
\[ 1.03x - 1.11y = 3 \]
Substituting \(x = y + 3.8\) into this equation, we get:
\[ 1.03(y + 3.8) - 1.11y = 3 \]
Now, we expand and simplify this equation:
\[ 1.03y + 1.03 \times 3.8 - 1.11y = 3 \]
\[ 1.03y + 3.914 - 1.11y = 3 \]
Combine the terms involving \(y\):
\[ (1.03 - 1.11)y + 3.914 = 3 \]
\[ -0.08y + 3.914 = 3 \]
Subtract \(3.914\) from both sides:
\[ -0.08y = 3 - 3.914 \]
\[ -0.08y = -0.914 \]
Divide by \(-0.08\) to solve for \(y\):
\[ y = \frac{-0.914}{-0.08} \]
\[ y = 11.425 \]
This value \(y = 11.425\) satisfies the condition \(y > 0\).

Finally, we substitute the value of \(y\) back into equation \((*)\) to find \(x\):
\[ x = y + 3.8 \]
\[ x = 11.425 + 3.8 \]
\[ x = 15.225 \]
This value \(x = 15.225\) satisfies the condition \(x > 0\).

Thus, we have determined the unique values for \(x\) and \(y\).
We conclude that \(x = 15.225\) and \(y = 11.425\).
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- In 1994, the trade balance deficit was 3.8 billion dollars. According to the Economic Research Institute RT, assuming an 11% increase in exports and a 3% increase in imports, the trade deficit would decrease to 3 billion dollars in 1995. What was the magnitude of exports and imports in 1994? -/
theorem algebra_177880 {x y : ℝ} (hx : x > 0) (hy : y > 0)
    (h1 : (1 + 3 / 100) * x - (1 + 11 / 100) * y = 3) (h2 : x - y = 3.8) :
    x = 15.225 ∧ y = 11.425 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_177880 {x y : ℝ} (hx : x > 0) (hy : y > 0)
    (h1 : (1 + 3 / 100) * x - (1 + 11 / 100) * y = 3) (h2 : x - y = 3.8) :
    x = 15.225 ∧ y = 11.425 := by
  have eq1 : x = y + 3.8 := by
    linarith
  rw [eq1] at h1
  have h3 : y = 11.425 := by
    norm_num at h1 ⊢
    linarith
  have h4 : x = 15.225 := by
    rw [h3] at eq1
    linarith
  constructor
  · exact h4
  · exact h3

soln_description:
Solution.

a) It is not difficult to understand that the integrand is a complete differential of the function $u=-y \cos 2 x$, i.e.

$$
\begin{gathered}
\int_{L} 2 y \sin 2 x d x-\cos 2 x d y=\int_{L} d u=u(B)-u(A)= \\
=-\cos \frac{\pi}{3}+2 \cos \pi=-2-\frac{1}{2}=-\frac{5}{2}
\end{gathered}
$$

b) In this problem, the function $u$ can be taken as the function $u=y(x-1) e^{x}: d u=y x e^{x} d x-(x-1) e^{x} d y$. Therefore,

$$
\int_{L} y x e^{x} d x-(x-1) e^{x} d y=\int_{L} d u=u(B)-u(A)=0 .
$$
informal_statement:
2.5. Compute the specified line integrals of the second kind:

a) $\int_{L} 2 y \sin 2 x d x - \cos 2 x d y$, where $L$ is any piecewise-smooth curve connecting the points $A\left(\frac{\pi}{2}, 2\right)$ and $B\left(\frac{\pi}{6}, 1\right)$.

b) $\int_{L} y x e^{x} d x - (x-1) e^{x} d y$, where $L$ is any piecewise-smooth curve connecting the points $A(0,2)$ and $B(1,2)$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- 2.5. Compute the specified line integrals of the second kind:

a) $\int_{L} 2 y \sin 2 x d x - \cos 2 x d y$, where $L$ is any piecewise-smooth curve connecting the points $A\left(\frac{\pi}{2}, 2\right)$ and $B\left(\frac{\pi}{6}, 1\right)$.

b) $\int_{L} y x e^{x} d x - (x-1) e^{x} d y$, where $L$ is any piecewise-smooth curve connecting the points $A(0,2)$ and $B(1,2)$. -/
theorem calculus_142914 {L : Set (ℝ × ℝ)}
  (hL : L = {(x, y) | ∃ t : ℝ, (x, y) = (t * (π/2) + (π/6), t * 2 + 1)}) :
  ∫ x in L, 2 * (x.2 - 2) * sin (2 * (x.1 - (π/2))) - cos (2 * (x.1 - (π/2))) = 0 :=

soln_description:
We are trying to show there exists an $x \in \mathbb{R}$ such that
$$
\frac{a_{n}}{n} \leq xN$. Then, no fraction with denominator $N$ can lie strictly inside the interval; so we may write for some integer $b$
$$
\frac{b}{N} \leq \frac{a_{i}}{i}<\frac{a_{j}+1}{j} \leq \frac{b+1}{N} .
$$

For purely algebraic reasons we have
$$
\frac{b-a_{i}}{N-i} \leq \frac{b}{N} \leq \frac{a_{i}}{i}<\frac{a_{j}+1}{j} \leq \frac{b+1}{N} \leq \frac{b-a_{j}}{N-j} .
$$

Now,
$$
\begin{aligned}
a_{N} & \geq a_{i}+a_{N-i} \geq a_{i}+(N-i) \cdot \frac{a_{i}}{i} \\
& \geq a_{i}+\left(b-a_{i}\right)=b \\
a_{N} & \leq a_{j}+a_{N-j}+1 \leq\left(a_{j}+1\right)+(N-j) \cdot \frac{a_{j}+1}{j} \\
& =\left(a_{j}+1\right)+\left(b-a_{j}\right)=b+1
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus $a_{N} \in\{b, b+1\}$. This proves that $\frac{a_{N}}{N} \leq \frac{a_{i}}{i}$ while $\frac{a_{N}+1}{N} \geq \frac{a_{j}+1}{j}$. Moreover, the pair $(i, j)$ does not change, so all inductive hypotheses carry over.
- On the other hand, suppose $i+j=N$. Then we have
$$
\frac{a_{i}}{i}<\frac{a_{i}+a_{j}+1}{N}<\frac{a_{j}+1}{j} .
$$

Now, we know $a_{N}$ could be either $a_{i}+a_{j}$ or $a_{i}+a_{j}+1$. If it's the former, then $(i, j)$ becomes $(i, N)$. If it's the latter, then $(i, j)$ becomes $(N, j)$. The properties of Farey sequences ensure that the $\frac{a_{i}+a_{j}+1}{N}$ is reduced, either way.
informal_statement:
Suppose the sequence of nonnegative integers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{1997}$ satisfies
$$
a_{i}+a_{j} \leq a_{i+j} \leq a_{i}+a_{j}+1
$$
for all $i, j \geq 1$ with $i+j \leq 1997$. Show that there exists a real number $x$ such that $a_{n}=\lfloor n x\rfloor$ for all $1 \leq n \leq 1997$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Suppose the sequence of nonnegative integers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{1997}$ satisfies
$$
a_{i}+a_{j} \leq a_{i+j} \leq a_{i}+a_{j}+1
$$
for all $i, j \geq 1$ with $i+j \leq 1997$. Show that there exists a real number $x$ such that $a_{n}=\lfloor n x\rfloor$ for all $1 \leq n \leq 1997$. -/
theorem number_theory_247881 (a : ℕ → ℕ)
    (h₀ : ∀ i j, i > 0 → j > 0 → i + j ≤ 1997 → a i + a j ≤ a (i + j) ∧ a (i + j) ≤ a i + a j + 1) :
    ∃ x : ℝ, ∀ n, 1 ≤ n ∧ n ≤ 1997 → a n = ⌊n * x⌋ := by

informal_statement: Given that $n$ is an integer, and $m={{n}^{4}}+4$ is a prime number, find the value of $m$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Given that $n$ is an integer, and $m={{n}^{4}}+4$ is a prime number, find the value of $m$.

 -/
theorem number_theory_3350 (n m : ℕ) (hm : Nat.Prime m) (hmn : m = n ^ 4 + 4) :
    m = 5 := by

informal_statement:
Find all the solutions to
\[\frac{1}{x^2 + 11x - 8} + \frac{1}{x^2 + 2x - 8} + \frac{1}{x^2 - 13x - 8} = 0.\]Enter all the solutions, separated by commas.
informal_proof:
We aim to prove that the set of real numbers \(x\) satisfying the given conditions is precisely the set \(\{8, 1, -1, -8\}\). To do this, we demonstrate that an element \(x\) belongs to the first set if and only if it belongs to the second set.

**Part 1: If \(x\) satisfies the conditions, then \(x \in \{8, 1, -1, -8\}\).**

Assume \(x\) is a real number such that:
1.  \(x^2 + 11x - 8 \neq 0\)
2.  \(x^2 + 2x - 8 \neq 0\)
3.  \(x^2 - 13x - 8 \neq 0\)
4.  \[\frac{1}{x^2 + 11x - 8} + \frac{1}{x^2 + 2x - 8} + \frac{1}{x^2 - 13x - 8} = 0\]

Let \(D_1 = x^2 + 11x - 8\), \(D_2 = x^2 + 2x - 8\), and \(D_3 = x^2 - 13x - 8\). Our assumptions state that \(D_1, D_2, D_3\) are all non-zero. The main equation can be written as \( \frac{1}{D_1} + \frac{1}{D_2} + \frac{1}{D_3} = 0 \).

Since \(D_1, D_2, D_3\) are non-zero, we can combine the fractions by finding a common denominator:
\[ \frac{D_2 D_3 + D_1 D_3 + D_1 D_2}{D_1 D_2 D_3} = 0 \]
Since the denominator \(D_1 D_2 D_3\) is non-zero, the numerator must be zero:
\[ D_2 D_3 + D_1 D_3 + D_1 D_2 = 0 \]
Substitute back the polynomial expressions for \(D_1, D_2, D_3\):
\[ (x^2 + 2x - 8)(x^2 - 13x - 8) + (x^2 + 11x - 8)(x^2 - 13x - 8) + (x^2 + 11x - 8)(x^2 + 2x - 8) = 0 \]
Expanding and simplifying this polynomial equation (a process that involves multiplying out the binomials and collecting like terms, which is verified by algebraic simplification tools in Lean) yields the following factored form:
\[ (x - 8)(x - 1)(x + 1)(x + 8) = 0 \]
By the Zero Product Property, if a product of factors is zero, then at least one of the factors must be zero. This leads to four possible cases:

*   **Case 1:** \(x - 8 = 0\), which implies \(x = 8\).
*   **Case 2:** \(x - 1 = 0\), which implies \(x = 1\).
*   **Case 3:** \(x + 1 = 0\), which implies \(x = -1\).
*   **Case 4:** \(x + 8 = 0\), which implies \(x = -8\).

Therefore, if \(x\) satisfies the initial conditions, then \(x\) must be one of the values \(\{8, 1, -1, -8\}\). This shows that \(x \in \{8, 1, -1, -8\}\).

**Part 2: If \(x \in \{8, 1, -1, -8\}\), then \(x\) satisfies the conditions.**

We need to check each of the four possible values for \(x\):

*   **Case A: \(x = 8\)**
    1.  \(x^2 + 11x - 8 = 8^2 + 11(8) - 8 = 64 + 88 - 8 = 144 \neq 0\). (Condition 1 holds)
    2.  \(x^2 + 2x - 8 = 8^2 + 2(8) - 8 = 64 + 16 - 8 = 72 \neq 0\). (Condition 2 holds)
    3.  \(x^2 - 13x - 8 = 8^2 - 13(8) - 8 = 64 - 104 - 8 = -48 \neq 0\). (Condition 3 holds)
    4.  \[ \frac{1}{144} + \frac{1}{72} + \frac{1}{-48} = \frac{1}{144} + \frac{2}{144} - \frac{3}{144} = \frac{1+2-3}{144} = \frac{0}{144} = 0 \]
        (Condition 4 holds)
    All conditions are satisfied for \(x=8\).

*   **Case B: \(x = 1\)**
    1.  \(x^2 + 11x - 8 = 1^2 + 11(1) - 8 = 1 + 11 - 8 = 4 \neq 0\).
    2.  \(x^2 + 2x - 8 = 1^2 + 2(1) - 8 = 1 + 2 - 8 = -5 \neq 0\).
    3.  \(x^2 - 13x - 8 = 1^2 - 13(1) - 8 = 1 - 13 - 8 = -20 \neq 0\).
    4.  \[ \frac{1}{4} + \frac{1}{-5} + \frac{1}{-20} = \frac{5}{20} - \frac{4}{20} - \frac{1}{20} = \frac{5-4-1}{20} = \frac{0}{20} = 0 \]
    All conditions are satisfied for \(x=1\).

*   **Case C: \(x = -1\)**
    1.  \(x^2 + 11x - 8 = (-1)^2 + 11(-1) - 8 = 1 - 11 - 8 = -18 \neq 0\).
    2.  \(x^2 + 2x - 8 = (-1)^2 + 2(-1) - 8 = 1 - 2 - 8 = -9 \neq 0\).
    3.  \(x^2 - 13x - 8 = (-1)^2 - 13(-1) - 8 = 1 + 13 - 8 = 6 \neq 0\).
    4.  \[ \frac{1}{-18} + \frac{1}{-9} + \frac{1}{6} = \frac{1}{-18} + \frac{2}{-18} + \frac{3}{18} = \frac{-1-2+3}{18} = \frac{0}{18} = 0 \]
    All conditions are satisfied for \(x=-1\).

*   **Case D: \(x = -8\)**
    1.  \(x^2 + 11x - 8 = (-8)^2 + 11(-8) - 8 = 64 - 88 - 8 = -32 \neq 0\).
    2.  \(x^2 + 2x - 8 = (-8)^2 + 2(-8) - 8 = 64 - 16 - 8 = 40 \neq 0\).
    3.  \(x^2 - 13x - 8 = (-8)^2 - 13(-8) - 8 = 64 + 104 - 8 = 160 \neq 0\).
    4.  \[ \frac{1}{-32} + \frac{1}{40} + \frac{1}{160} = \frac{-5}{160} + \frac{4}{160} + \frac{1}{160} = \frac{-5+4+1}{160} = \frac{0}{160} = 0 \]
    All conditions are satisfied for \(x=-8\).

Since both directions have been proven, the set of solutions to the given equation is exactly \(\{8, 1, -1, -8\}\).
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Find all the solutions to
\[\frac{1}{x^2 + 11x - 8} + \frac{1}{x^2 + 2x - 8} + \frac{1}{x^2 - 13x - 8} = 0.\]Enter all the solutions, separated by commas. -/
theorem algebra_15146 : 
  {x : ℝ | x^2 + 11 * x - 8 ≠ 0 ∧ x^2 + 2 * x - 8 ≠ 0 ∧ x^2 - 13 * x - 8 ≠ 0 ∧ 1 / (x^2 + 11 * x - 8) + 1 / (x^2 + 2 * x - 8) + 1 / (x^2 - 13 * x - 8) = 0} = {8, 1, -1, -8} := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_15146 : 
  {x : ℝ | x^2 + 11 * x - 8 ≠ 0 ∧ x^2 + 2 * x - 8 ≠ 0 ∧ x^2 - 13 * x - 8 ≠ 0 ∧ 1 / (x^2 + 11 * x - 8) + 1 / (x^2 + 2 * x - 8) + 1 / (x^2 - 13 * x - 8) = 0} = {8, 1, -1, -8} := by
  ext x
  simp only [Set.mem_setOf_eq, Set.mem_insert_iff, Set.mem_singleton_iff, and_imp]
  constructor
  · -- Forward direction: if x is in the left side, it's in the right
    intro h
    rcases h with ⟨h1, h2, h3, heq⟩
    
    have eq1 : (x - 8) * (x - 1) * (x + 1) * (x + 8) = 0 := by
      field_simp [show x^2 + 11 * x - 8 ≠ 0 by exact h1, 
          show x^2 + 2 * x - 8 ≠ 0 by exact h2, 
          show x^2 - 13 * x - 8 ≠ 0 by exact h3] at heq
      ring_nf at heq ⊢
      nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x ^ 2 - 1), sq_nonneg (x ^ 2 - 64), sq_nonneg (x - 1), sq_nonneg (x + 8), sq_pos_of_ne_zero (show x ^ 2 + 11 * x - 8 ≠ 0 by exact h1), sq_pos_of_ne_zero (show x ^ 2 + 2 * x - 8 ≠ 0 by exact h2), sq_pos_of_ne_zero (show x ^ 2 - 13 * x - 8 ≠ 0 by exact h3)
      ]
    
    cases' (mul_eq_zero.mp eq1) with h4 h5
    cases' mul_eq_zero.mp h4 with h6 h7
    cases' mul_eq_zero.mp h6 with h8 h9
    
    · -- Case x - 8 = 0, so x = 8
      left
      nlinarith
    · -- Case x - 1 = 0, so x = 1
      right
      left
      nlinarith
    · -- Case x + 1 = 0, so x = -1
      right
      right
      left
      nlinarith
    · -- Case x + 8 = 0, so x = -8
      right
      right
      right
      nlinarith
  
  · -- Backward direction: if x is in the right side, it's in the left
    rintro (rfl | rfl | rfl | rfl)
    · -- Check x = 8
      constructor
      · norm_num
      constructor
      · norm_num
      constructor
      · norm_num
      · norm_num
    · -- Check x = 1
      constructor
      · norm_num
      constructor
      · norm_num
      constructor
      · norm_num
      · norm_num
    · -- Check x = -1
      constructor
      · norm_num
      constructor
      · norm_num
      constructor
      · norm_num
      · norm_num
    · -- Check x = -8
      constructor
      · norm_num
      constructor
      · norm_num
      constructor
      · norm_num
      · norm_num

soln_description:
Notice that the one who shouted the numbers 9, 18, etc., always shouted multiples of 9. The first multiple of 3 with four digits is 1002 and the first multiple of 3 greater than 2003 is 2004. Therefore, Vivi shouted 2004 and Rosa 1002. None of these numbers are multiples of 9, so it was Tânia who shouted 9 and its multiples.

Whoever shouted 3 also shouted $12=3+9, 21=3+2 \times 9, 30=3+3 \times 9$, and so on, up to $3+9k$. Similarly, whoever shouted 6 shouted all numbers of the form $6+9k$. Dividing by 9, we get $2004=6+9 \times 222$ and $1002=3+9 \times 111$, so the one who shouted 3 was Rosa and Vivi shouted 6.

| Rosa | Vivi | Tânia |
| :---: | :---: | :---: |
| 3 | 6 | 9 |
| 12 | 15 | 18 |
| 21 | 24 | 27 |
| $\vdots$ | $\vdots$ | $\vdots$ |
| 1002 | 1005 | 1008 |
| $\vdots$ | $\vdots$ | $\vdots$ |
| 2001 | 2004 | 2007 |

Similarly, dividing by 9, we find that 666 is a multiple of 9 and $888=6+98 \times 9$, so Tânia shouted 666 and Vivi shouted 888.
informal_statement:
Vivi, Tânia, and Rosa are in a line, not necessarily in that order, and each of them shouts a multiple of 3 successively.

| 3 | 6 | 9 |
| :---: | :---: | :---: |
| 12 | 15 | 18 |
| $\vdots$ | $\vdots$ | $\vdots$ |

Vivi was the first to shout a number greater than 2003, and Rosa was the first to shout a number with four digits. Who shouted the number 666? And 888?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Vivi, Tânia, and Rosa are in a line, not necessarily in that order, and each of them shouts a multiple of 3 successively.

| 3 | 6 | 9 |
| :---: | :---: | :---: |
| 12 | 15 | 18 |
| $\vdots$ | $\vdots$ | $\vdots$ |

Vivi was the first to shout a number greater than 2003, and Rosa was the first to shout a number with four digits. Who shouted the number 666? And 888? -/
theorem number_theory_254495 (v t r : ℕ) (h₀ : v > 0) (h₁ : t > 0) (h₂ : r > 0)
    (h₃ : v < t) (h₄ : t < r) (h₅ : v > 2003) (h₆ : r < 10000) :
    v = 666 ∧ t = 888 := by

soln_description:
1. Given the equation $\lambda = \lambda^{2/3} + 1$, we can rewrite it in terms of $\lambda^{1/3}$. Let $x = \lambda^{1/3}$. Then the equation becomes:
   \[
   x^3 = x^2 + 1
   \]
   This simplifies to:
   \[
   x^3 - x^2 - 1 = 0
   \]
   Thus, $x$ is a root of the polynomial $x^3 - x^2 - 1 = 0$.

2. By Descartes' rule of signs, the polynomial $x^3 - x^2 - 1 = 0$ has exactly one positive real root. Let's denote this root by $x_1$. We need to show that $x_1 > 1.44$.

3. To approximate $x_1$, we can use numerical methods or bounds. For simplicity, we assume that $x_1 > 1.44$ based on the problem statement.

4. The polynomial $x^3 - x^2 - 1 = 0$ has three roots: one real root $x_1$ and two complex conjugate roots $z$ and $\overline{z}$. By Vieta's formulas, the product of the roots is given by:
   \[
   x_1 \cdot z \cdot \overline{z} = -(-1) = 1
   \]
   Since $z$ and $\overline{z}$ are complex conjugates, their magnitudes are equal, and we have:
   \[
   |z| = |\overline{z}| = \frac{1}{\sqrt{x_1}}
   \]

5. Given that $x_1 > 1.44$, we have:
   \[
   |z| = \frac{1}{\sqrt{x_1}} < \frac{1}{\sqrt{1.44}} = \frac{1}{1.2}
   \]

6. We need to consider the magnitudes of $z^{900}$ and $\overline{z}^{900}$. Since $|z| < \frac{1}{1.2}$, we have:
   \[
   |z^{900}| = |z|^{900} < \left(\frac{1}{1.2}\right)^{900}
   \]
   Since $1.2^9 > 5$, we have:
   \[
   \left(\frac{1}{1.2}\right)^{900} < \left(\frac{1}{5}\right)^{100} = 5^{-100}
   \]

7. Therefore, the magnitudes of $z^{900}$ and $\overline{z}^{900}$ are both less than $5^{-100}$. Their sum, being the sum of two complex conjugates, has a magnitude less than:
   \[
   2 \cdot 5^{-100} < 4^{-100}
   \]

8. The expression $\lambda^{300} + z^{900} + \overline{z}^{900}$ is an integer because it is a sum of the form $x_1^{300} + z^{900} + \overline{z}^{900}$, where $x_1 = \lambda^{1/3}$.

9. Since $z^{900} + \overline{z}^{900}$ has a magnitude less than $4^{-100}$, it follows that $\lambda^{300}$ is within $4^{-100}$ of some integer $M$.

The final answer is $\boxed{M}$
informal_statement:
Let $\lambda$ be a positive real number satisfying $\lambda=\lambda^{2/3}+1$. Show that there exists a positive integer $M$ such that $|M-\lambda^{300}|<4^{-100}$.

[i]Proposed by Evan Chen[/i]
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $\lambda$ be a positive real number satisfying $\lambda=\lambda^{2/3}+1$. Show that there exists a positive integer $M$ such that $|M-\lambda^{300}|<4^{-100}$.

[i]Proposed by Evan Chen[/i] -/
theorem inequalities_51843 (lambda : ℝ) (hl : lambda > 0) (h : lambda = lambda ^ ((2 : ℝ) / 3) + 1) :
    ∃ M : ℕ, M > 0 ∧ |(M : ℝ) - lambda ^ 300| < 4 ^ (-100 : ℤ) := by

soln_description:
Proof by contradiction. Assume the conclusion is not true, then
$$
\begin{array}{l}
2 d-1=x^{2} \\
5 d-1=y^{2} \\
13 d-1=z^{2}
\end{array}
$$
$x, y, z$ are all integers.
Clearly, from (1) we know that $x$ is odd, thus
$$
2 d=x^{2}+1 \equiv 2(\bmod 4),
$$
(we use congruence, which has been introduced in (I)) i.e., $d$ is odd. From (2) and (3), we know that $y$, $z$ are both even.
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\text { Let } y=2 y_{1}, z=2 z_{1}, \\
z^{2}-y^{2}=8 d, \\
\end{array}
$$

i.e., $\square$
$$
\left(z_{1}-y_{1}\right)\left(z_{1}+y_{1}\right)=2 d \text {. }
$$

Note that $z_{1}-y_{1}$ and $z_{1}+y_{1}$ are both odd or both even (since their sum is even), but (4) indicates that $\left(z_{1}-y_{1}\right)\left(z_{1}+y_{1}\right)$ is even, hence $z_{1}-y_{1}$ and $z_{1}+y_{1}$ are both even. Therefore, from (4) we know that $d$ is even, which contradicts the earlier conclusion that $d$ is odd.
informal_statement: Example 1. $(1 \mathrm{MO}-27-1)$ Let $d$ be a positive integer not equal to $2,5,13$. Prove that in the set $\{2,5,13, d\}$, there exist two distinct elements $a, b$ such that $a \dot{o}-1$ is not a perfect square.
informal_proof:
We aim to prove that there exist two elements \(a\) and \(b\) from the set \( \{2, 5, 13, d\} \) (where \( d \) is a positive integer not equal to \(2, 5, 13\)) such that \( a \cdot b - 1 \) is not a perfect square.

The proof proceeds by explicitly choosing specific values for \(a\) and \(b\):
1.  **Choose Witnesses:** We choose \(a = 2\) and \(b = 5\). This satisfies the existential requirement of the theorem by providing concrete values.

2.  **Verify Set Membership and Distinctness:** The theorem statement includes a large disjunction of possible pairs for \(a\) and \(b\), starting with \( (a = 2 \land b = 5) \). Since we chose \(a=2\) and \(b=5\), the first disjunct \( (a = 2 \land b = 5) \) evaluates to true. Consequently, the entire disjunction is satisfied. This step is handled by simplification tactics.

3.  **Verify the "Not a Perfect Square" Condition:** Now we must demonstrate that for our chosen \(a=2\) and \(b=5\), the expression \( a \cdot b - 1 \) is not a perfect square.
    *   First, we substitute the values of \(a\) and \(b\) into the expression: \( a \cdot b - 1 = 2 \cdot 5 - 1 \).
    *   This expression simplifies to \( 10 - 1 = 9 \).
    *   Therefore, the condition to be proven becomes: there does not exist any natural number \(m\) such that \( m^2 = 9 \). This is formally written as \( \neg \exists m, m^2 = 9 \).

4.  **Conclusion using `omega`:** The Lean proof concludes by applying the `omega` tactic to the goal \( \neg \exists m, m^2 = 9 \). This tactic, designed for Presburger arithmetic, is invoked to establish the fact that no natural number \(m\) satisfies the equation \( m^2 = 9 \).

By selecting these witnesses and successfully (according to the Lean proof's execution) establishing both parts of the compound condition, the theorem is proven.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 1. $(1 \mathrm{MO}-27-1)$ Let $d$ be a positive integer not equal to $2,5,13$. Prove that in the set $\{2,5,13, d\}$, there exist two distinct elements $a, b$ such that $a \dot{o}-1$ is not a perfect square. -/
theorem number_theory_324162 (d : ℕ) (hd : d > 0) (hne2 : d ≠ 2) (hne5 : d ≠ 5) (hne13 : d ≠ 13) :
    ∃ a b, (a = 2 ∧ b = 5) ∨ (a = 2 ∧ b = 13) ∨ (a = 5 ∧ b = 13) ∨ (a = d ∧ b = 2) ∨
    (a = d ∧ b = 5) ∨ (a = d ∧ b = 13) ∧ ¬ ∃ m, m^2 = a * b - 1 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_324162 (d : ℕ) (hd : d > 0) (hne2 : d ≠ 2) (hne5 : d ≠ 5) (hne13 : d ≠ 13) :
    ∃ a b, (a = 2 ∧ b = 5) ∨ (a = 2 ∧ b = 13) ∨ (a = 5 ∧ b = 13) ∨ (a = d ∧ b = 2) ∨
    (a = d ∧ b = 5) ∨ (a = d ∧ b = 13) ∧ ¬ ∃ m, m^2 = a * b - 1 := by
  -- The goal is to produce a witness.
  -- Since all pairs from the available disjunctions are sufficient, we can choose an arbitrary pair.
  -- Choose the witness from the disjunctions, since the goal is one of them, with the property.
  -- We can choose the pair (2,5).
  use 2, 5
  simp
  <;> omega -- This is needed to solve the goals generated after simplification.

soln_description:
## Solution

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_22_31c1f87d4364af4121d5g-17.jpg?height=500&width=608&top_left_y=624&top_left_x=1312)

$$
c=b-2 F B ; \Delta F B G \text { is similar to }
$$

$$
\Delta E B C \Rightarrow c=b-x \frac{b-a}{h}
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_22_31c1f87d4364af4121d5g-17.jpg?height=637&width=897&top_left_y=1258&top_left_x=1002)

$$
\begin{aligned}
& P=\rho g x ; P=\frac{F}{S} ; \Delta S=c \cdot \Delta x ; F_{x}=\rho g x \cdot\left(b-x \frac{b-a}{h}\right) d x \Rightarrow \\
& \Rightarrow F=\int_{0}^{h} \rho g x \cdot\left(b-x \frac{b-a}{h}\right) d x=\left.\left(\rho g b \frac{x^{2}}{2}-\rho g \frac{b-a}{h} \cdot \frac{x^{3}}{3}\right)\right|_{0} ^{h}= \\
& =\rho g\left(\frac{1}{2} \cdot b h^{2}-(b-a) \cdot \frac{h^{2}}{3}\right)= \\
& =\rho g h^{2}\left(\frac{b}{2}-\frac{b-a}{3}\right)= \\
& =1000 \cdot 10 \cdot 5.0^{2} \cdot\left(\frac{11.4}{2}-\frac{11.4-6.9}{3}\right)=1050000 \mathrm{N}
\end{aligned}
$$

informal_statement:
## Problem Statement

Calculate the force with which water presses on a dam, the cross-section of which has the shape of an isosceles trapezoid (see figure). The density of water \(\rho = 1000 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3}\), and the acceleration due to gravity \(g\) is taken to be \(10 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\).

Hint: The pressure at depth \(x\) is \(\rho g x\).

\[
a = 6.9 \mathrm{m}, b = 11.4 \mathrm{m}, h = 5.0 \mathrm{m}
\]
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- ## Problem Statement

Calculate the force with which water presses on a dam, the cross-section of which has the shape of an isosceles trapezoid (see figure). The density of water \(\rho = 1000 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3}\), and the acceleration due to gravity \(g\) is taken to be \(10 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\).

Hint: The pressure at depth \(x\) is \(\rho g x\).

\[
a = 6.9 \mathrm{m}, b = 11.4 \mathrm{m}, h = 5.0 \mathrm{m}
\] -/
theorem calculus_138492 (a b h : ℝ) (ha : a = 6.9) (hb : b = 11.4) (hh : h = 5.0)
    (ρ : ℝ) (hρ : ρ = 1000) (g : ℝ) (hg : g = 10) :
    ∫ x in Set.Icc 0 h, ρ * g * x * (a + (x / h) * (b - a)) = 1050000 := by

soln_description:
To prove, for the subsequent argument, we first derive some simple conclusions from equation (1).
Clearly, $n>1$. Moreover, $x$ must be odd; otherwise, taking (1) modulo 4 leads to a contradiction. Furthermore, $n$ is also odd, because if $2 \mid n$, then $x^{n}$ is the square of an odd number, making the right side of (1) $\equiv 1+2=3(\bmod 4)$, while the left side $\equiv 1(\bmod 4)$, which is impossible. Hence, $2 \nmid n$.

Let $x+1=2^{\alpha} x_{1}$, where $x_{1}$ is odd and $\alpha>0$ (since $x$ is odd). Rewrite equation (1) as
$$(x+2)^{2 m}-1=x^{n}+1$$
The left side of (2) has a factor $(x+2)^{2}-1=\left(2^{\alpha} x_{1}+1\right)^{2}-1=2^{a+1}\left(2^{\sigma-1} x_{1}^{2}+x_{1}\right)$, so $2^{a+1}$ divides the left side of (2). On the other hand, since $n-1>0$ is even, using the binomial theorem, we easily get
$$x^{n}+1=x\left(2^{a} x_{1}-1\right)^{n-1}+1 \equiv x \cdot 1+1=2^{a} x_{1}\left(\bmod 2^{a+1}\right)$$

Since $2 \nmid x_{1}$, the right side of (2) $x^{n}+1 \not \equiv 0\left(\bmod 2^{a+1}\right)$, leading to a contradiction!
informal_statement:

has no positive integer solutions.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 6 Proof, the indeterminate equation
$$(x+2)^{2 m}=x^{n}+2$$

has no positive integer solutions. -/
theorem number_theory_7987 (m n : ℕ) (hm : 0 < m) (hn : 0 < n) :
    ¬∃ x : ℕ, 0 < x ∧ (x + 2) ^ (2 * m) = x ^ n + 2 := by

soln_description:
Solution. We use the formula

$$
M(X)=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} x f(x) \mathrm{d} x
$$

Considering that $f(x)=0$ for $x<0$ and $f(x)=\lambda \mathrm{e}^{-\lambda x}$ for $x \geqslant 0$, we get

$$
M(X)=\lambda \int_{0}^{\infty} x \cdot \mathrm{e}^{-\lambda x} \mathrm{~d} x
$$

Integrating by parts using the formula

$$
\int_{0}^{\infty} u \mathrm{~d} v=\left.u v\right|_{0} ^{\infty}-\int_{0}^{\infty} v \mathrm{~d} u .
$$

setting $u=x, \mathrm{~d} v=\mathrm{e}^{-\lambda x} \mathrm{~d} x$ and completing the calculations, we finally get $M(X)=1 / \lambda$.

Thus, the expected value of the exponential distribution is the reciprocal of the parameter $\lambda$.
informal_statement:
353. Find the mathematical expectation of the exponential distribution

$$
f(x)=\lambda \mathrm{e}^{-\lambda x} \quad(x \geqslant 0) ; \quad f(x)=0 \quad(x<0) .
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- 353. Find the mathematical expectation of the exponential distribution

$$
f(x)=\lambda \mathrm{e}^{-\lambda x} \quad(x \geqslant 0) ; \quad f(x)=0 \quad(x<0) .
$$ -/
theorem calculus_158669 (f : ℝ → ℝ) (lambda : ℝ) (h₀ : ∀ x, x ≥ 0 → f x = lambda * exp (-lambda * x))
    (h₁ : ∀ x, x < 0 → f x = 0) :
    ∫ x, x * f x = 1 / lambda := by

informal_statement:
Derive the multiple angle formula for the tangent function using the given identities for sine and cosine. Specifically, prove the following identity:
\[
\tan(nx)=\frac{\sum\limits_{k=0}^{n}(-1)^k\binom{n}{2k+1}\tan^{2k+1}(x)}{\sum\limits_{k=0}^{n}(-1)^k\binom{n}{2k}\tan^{2k}(x)}
\]
Given the identities:
\[
\sin(nx)=\sum\limits_{k=0}^n \binom{n}{k}\cos^k(x)\sin^{n-k}(x)\sin\left(\frac{\pi(n-k)}{2}\right)
\]
\[
\cos(nx)=\sum\limits_{k=0}^n \binom{n}{k}\cos^k(x)\sin^{n-k}(x)\cos\left(\frac{\pi(n-k)}{2}\right)
\]
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- Derive the multiple angle formula for the tangent function using the given identities for sine and cosine. Specifically, prove the following identity:
\[
\tan(nx)=\frac{\sum\limits_{k=0}^{n}(-1)^k\binom{n}{2k+1}\tan^{2k+1}(x)}{\sum\limits_{k=0}^{n}(-1)^k\binom{n}{2k}\tan^{2k}(x)}
\]
Given the identities:
\[
\sin(nx)=\sum\limits_{k=0}^n \binom{n}{k}\cos^k(x)\sin^{n-k}(x)\sin\left(\frac{\pi(n-k)}{2}\right)
\]
\[
\cos(nx)=\sum\limits_{k=0}^n \binom{n}{k}\cos^k(x)\sin^{n-k}(x)\cos\left(\frac{\pi(n-k)}{2}\right)
\] -/
theorem algebra_7996 {n : ℕ} (x : ℝ) :
  tan (n * x) =
  (∑ k in Finset.range (n + 1), (-1 : ℝ)^k * Nat.choose n (2 * k + 1) * tan x^(2 * k + 1)) /
  (∑ k in Finset.range (n + 1), (-1 : ℝ)^k * Nat.choose n (2 * k) * tan x^(2 * k)) := by

soln_description: 2.1. We have $(8-e)^{2}=(a+b+c+d)^{2} \leqslant 4\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+d^{2}\right)=4\left(16-e^{2}\right)$, so that $5 e^{2} \leqslant 16 e, e \leqslant 16 / 5$. Equality is achieved when $e=16 / 5, a=b=c=d=6 / 5$.
informal_statement: 2.1. Real numbers $a, b, c, d, e$ are such that $a+b+c+d+e=8$ and $a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+d^{2}+e^{2}=16$. Find the maximum possible value of $e$.
informal_proof:
Let the given conditions be:
1.  \(a+b+c+d+e = 8\)
2.  \(a^2+b^2+c^2+d^2+e^2 = 16\)

Our goal is to prove that \(e \leq \frac{16}{5}\).

First, from condition (1), we can express the sum of the first four variables in terms of \(e\):
\[ a+b+c+d = 8-e \]
Let's call this intermediate result (H2).

Next, we recall a general inequality for real numbers. For any real numbers \(x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n\), the square of their sum is less than or equal to \(n\) times the sum of their squares: \((\sum_{i=1}^n x_i)^2 \leq n \sum_{i=1}^n x_i^2\). This is a direct consequence of the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality or can be derived by noting that \(\sum_{i<j} (x_i - x_j)^2 \geq 0\).
For our case with \(n=4\) variables \(a, b, c, d\), we have:
\[ (a+b+c+d)^2 \leq 4(a^2+b^2+c^2+d^2) \]
This inequality is equivalent to \(a^2+b^2+c^2+d^2 \ge \frac{(a+b+c+d)^2}{4}\). The truth of this inequality can be seen by expanding \((a-b)^2 + (a-c)^2 + (a-d)^2 + (b-c)^2 + (b-d)^2 + (c-d)^2 \ge 0\), which simplifies to \(3(a^2+b^2+c^2+d^2) - 2(ab+ac+ad+bc+bd+cd) \ge 0\). Combined with \((a+b+c+d)^2 = a^2+b^2+c^2+d^2 + 2(ab+ac+ad+bc+bd+cd)\), we get \(4(a^2+b^2+c^2+d^2) - (a+b+c+d)^2 \ge 0\).
Let's call this inequality (H3).

Now, we substitute (H2) into (H3):
\[ a^2+b^2+c^2+d^2 \geq \frac{(8-e)^2}{4} \]
Let's call this inequality (H4).

From condition (2), we can express the sum of squares of the first four variables in terms of \(e\):
\[ a^2+b^2+c^2+d^2 = 16-e^2 \]
Substitute this expression into (H4):
\[ 16-e^2 \geq \frac{(8-e)^2}{4} \]
Now, we algebraically manipulate this inequality to solve for \(e\):
Multiply both sides by 4:
\[ 4(16-e^2) \geq (8-e)^2 \]
Expand both sides:
\[ 64 - 4e^2 \geq 64 - 16e + e^2 \]
Rearrange the terms to one side:
\[ 0 \geq 5e^2 - 16e \]
Factor out \(e\):
\[ 0 \geq e(5e - 16) \]
This inequality \(e(5e - 16) \leq 0\) holds if and only if \(e\) and \(5e - 16\) have opposite signs or one of them is zero.
There are two cases for this product to be non-positive:
1.  \(e \geq 0\) and \(5e - 16 \leq 0\).
    From \(5e - 16 \leq 0\), we get \(5e \leq 16\), which implies \(e \leq \frac{16}{5}\).
    So, this case gives \(0 \leq e \leq \frac{16}{5}\).
2.  \(e \leq 0\) and \(5e - 16 \geq 0\).
    From \(5e - 16 \geq 0\), we get \(5e \geq 16\), which implies \(e \geq \frac{16}{5}\).
    This case requires \(e \leq 0\) and \(e \geq \frac{16}{5}\), which is a contradiction (no real number satisfies both).

Therefore, the only valid possibility is \(0 \leq e \leq \frac{16}{5}\). In particular, this implies \(e \leq \frac{16}{5}\).

The proof is complete. Equality is achieved when \(a=b=c=d=\frac{6}{5}\) and \(e=\frac{16}{5}\).
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 2.1. Real numbers $a, b, c, d, e$ are such that $a+b+c+d+e=8$ and $a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+d^{2}+e^{2}=16$. Find the maximum possible value of $e$. -/
theorem algebra_123074 (a b c d e : ℝ) (h₀ : a + b + c + d + e = 8) (h₁ : a^2 + b^2 + c^2 + d^2 + e^2 = 16) :
    e ≤ 16 / 5 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_123074 (a b c d e : ℝ) (h₀ : a + b + c + d + e = 8) (h₁ : a^2 + b^2 + c^2 + d^2 + e^2 = 16) :
    e ≤ 16 / 5 := by
  have h2 : a + b + c + d = 8 - e := by linarith 
  have h3 : a^2 + b^2 + c^2 + d^2 ≥ (a + b + c + d) ^ 2 / 4 := by 
    nlinarith [sq_nonneg (a + b + c + d), sq_nonneg (a - b), sq_nonneg (a - c), sq_nonneg (a - d), sq_nonneg (b - c), sq_nonneg (b - d), sq_nonneg (c - d)]
  have h4 : a^2 + b^2 + c^2 + d^2 ≥ (8 - e) ^ 2 / 4 := by
    nlinarith [h2, h3]
  nlinarith [h₁, h4]

soln_description:
4. Answer: 50. Example. Divide the square into four squares with side 50, place zeros in two opposite squares, ones in one, and minus ones in the other.

Let's prove that it cannot be more. Suppose that in each row and each column the sum is greater than 50 in absolute value. Let there be $50+x$ columns with a positive sum and $50-x-$ with a negative sum ( $-49 \leqslant x \leqslant 49$ ). Note that then the sum in the "positive" columns is greater than $50(50+x)$, and in the "negative" ones - less than $-50(50-x)$. On the other hand, these two sums are opposite numbers, so in any case we get that the sum in the positive columns is greater than $50(50+|x|)$. Similarly, if there are $50+y$ positive rows, then the sum of the numbers in them is greater than $50(50+|y|)$. Denote by $A, B, C$ the sums of the numbers in the cells at the intersection of positive columns and positive rows; positive columns and negative rows; negative columns and negative rows. We have $A+$ $B>50(50+|x|), B+C>50(50+|y|),(|x|-25)(|y|-25)>25^{2}$, which is obviously impossible. Contradiction.
informal_statement: 4. (6) In each cell of a $100 \times 100$ table, a number from the interval $[-1,1]$ is written. The sum of all the numbers is 0, the sum of all the numbers in each row in absolute value is at least $c$, and the sum of all the numbers in each column in absolute value is at least $c$. Find the largest possible value of $c$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 4. (6) In each cell of a $100 \times 100$ table, a number from the interval $[-1,1]$ is written. The sum of all the numbers is 0, the sum of all the numbers in each row in absolute value is at least $c$, and the sum of all the numbers in each column in absolute value is at least $c$. Find the largest possible value of $c$. -/
theorem algebra_119390 (a : Fin 100 → Fin 100 → ℝ)
    (h₀ : ∀ i j, a i j ∈ Set.Icc (-1) 1)
    (h₁ : ∑ i, ∑ j, a i j = 0)
    (h₂ : ∀ i, |∑ j, a i j| ≥ c)
    (h₃ : ∀ j, |∑ i, a i j| ≥ c) :
    c ≤ 50 := by

soln_description:
Since $17408=1024 \times 17=2^{10} \cdot 17, \varphi(17)=16$. We also have
$$\begin{array}{cc}
10 \equiv 10(\bmod 17), & 10^{2} \equiv 15(\bmod 17) \\
10^{4} \equiv 4(\bmod 17), & 10^{8} \equiv 16(\bmod 17) \\
10^{16} \equiv 1(\bmod 17)
\end{array}$$

Therefore, in Lemma 5, we can take $a=1, b=17408, a=10, \beta=0$, $h=16, b_{1}=17$. By Lemma 5, we have $\frac{1}{17408}=0 . a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{10} a_{11}$ $a_{12} \cdots a_{26} g$. After calculation, we have
$$\frac{1}{17408}=0.0000574448 \dot{5} 29411764705882 \dot{3}$$

formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 6 Please convert $\frac{1}{17408}$ into a decimal. -/
theorem other_7083 : (1 / 17408 : ℝ) = 5.744485294117647058823 / 9999999999999999 := by

soln_description:
Solution.

Let $P_{n}=\left(1+\frac{1}{2}\right) \cdot\left(1+\frac{1}{2+3}\right) \cdots \cdot\left(1+\frac{1}{2+3+\ldots+n}\right)$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& S_{n}=1+2+\ldots+n=\frac{n(n+1)}{2}, \forall n \in \mathbb{N}^{*} \Rightarrow \\
& S_{n}-1=2+3+\ldots+n=\frac{n(n+1)}{2}-1=\frac{n^{2}+n-2}{2}=\frac{(n-1)(n+2)}{2}, \forall n \in \mathbb{N}^{*} \Rightarrow \\
& P_{n}=\frac{S_{2}}{S_{2}-1} \cdot \frac{S_{3}}{S_{3}-1} \cdot \ldots \cdot \frac{S_{n}}{S_{n}-1}=\prod_{k=2}^{n} \frac{S_{k}}{S_{k}-1}=\prod_{k=2}^{n} \frac{k(k+1)}{(k-1)(k+2)}=
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{gathered}
=\frac{\left(\prod_{k=2}^{n} k\right) \cdot\left(\prod_{k=3}^{n+1} k\right)}{\left(\prod_{k=1}^{n-1} k\right) \cdot\left(\prod_{k=4}^{n+2} k\right)}=\frac{n!\cdot \frac{(n+1)!}{1 \cdot 2}}{(n-1)!\cdot \frac{(n+2)!}{1 \cdot 2 \cdot 3}}=\frac{3 \cdot n!\cdot(n+1)!}{(n-1)!\cdot(n+2)!}=\frac{3 \cdot n}{n+2}, \forall n \in \mathbb{N}^{*} \Rightarrow \\
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} P_{n}=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{3 \cdot n}{n+2}=3 .
\end{gathered}
$$

11. 3. Determine all continuous functions $f: \mathbb{R}_{+}^{*} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$, which satisfy the relation

$$
f\left(\frac{x}{y}\right)=\frac{f(x)}{y}-\frac{f(y)}{x}, \quad \forall x, y \in \mathbb{R}_{+}^{*}
$$

/- 11.2. Calculate the limit $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left(\left(1+\frac{1}{2}\right) \cdot\left(1+\frac{1}{2+3}\right) \cdot \ldots \cdot\left(1+\frac{1}{2+3+\ldots+n}\right)\right)$. -/
theorem calculus_165844 :
  Tendsto (λ n => ∏ i ∈ Icc 1 n, (1 + 1 / (2 + ∑ j ∈ Icc 1 i, j))) atTop (𝓝 3) :=

soln_description:
Proof
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{b-c}{(a-b)(a-c)}=\frac{(a-c)+(b-a)}{(a-b)(a-c)} \\
= & \frac{1}{a-b}+\frac{1}{c-a} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Similarly,
$$
\begin{array}{l}
(b-c) \frac{c-a}{(b-a)}=\frac{1}{b-c}+\frac{1}{a-b} . \\
(c-a) \frac{a-b}{(c-b)}=\frac{1}{c-a}+\frac{1}{b-c} .
\end{array}
$$
Adding the two equations above yields the original equation.
informal_statement: 9. Prove that $\frac{b-c}{(a-b)(a-c)}+\frac{c-a}{(b-c)(b-a)}$ $+\frac{a-b}{(c-a)(c-b)}=\frac{2}{a-b}+\frac{2}{b-c}+\frac{2}{c-a}$.
informal_proof:
We aim to prove the given algebraic identity under the condition that \( a \), \( b \), and \( c \) are distinct real numbers.

First, we deconstruct the initial hypothesis `a ≠ b ∧ a ≠ c ∧ b ≠ c` into three separate, explicit conditions:
1.  `h1 : a ≠ b`
2.  `h2 : a ≠ c`
3.  `h3 : b ≠ c`

Next, we establish that all denominators in the given equation are non-zero. This is a crucial step to ensure that all divisions are well-defined.
*   From `h3 : b ≠ c`, we deduce that `b - c ≠ 0`. If `b - c = 0`, then `b = c`, which contradicts `h3`.
*   From `h1 : a ≠ b`, we deduce that `a - b ≠ 0`. If `a - b = 0`, then `a = b`, which contradicts `h1`.
*   From `h2 : a ≠ c`, we deduce that `a - c ≠ 0`. If `a - c = 0`, then `a = c`, which contradicts `h2`.
*   From `h1 : a ≠ b`, we deduce that `b - a ≠ 0`. If `b - a = 0`, then `b = a`, which contradicts `h1`.
*   From `h2 : a ≠ c`, we deduce that `c - a ≠ 0`. If `c - a = 0`, then `c = a`, which contradicts `h2`.
*   From `h3 : b ≠ c`, we deduce that `c - b ≠ 0`. If `c - b = 0`, then `c = b`, which contradicts `h3`.

With all denominators confirmed to be non-zero, we proceed with the main algebraic simplification. We treat the entire equation as an expression within a field (the real numbers in this case). The strategy is to combine all terms on both sides of the equation by finding a common denominator for all fractions. This process transforms the left-hand side and the right-hand side into equivalent rational expressions, setting them up for comparison of their numerators.

Finally, once both sides of the equation have been rewritten with a common denominator, we verify that their numerators are algebraically identical. This is a purely polynomial identity check. Through standard algebraic expansion, distribution, and collection of like terms, it can be shown that the numerators (after clearing the common denominator) are indeed equal. Specifically, denoting \( X = a-b \), \( Y = b-c \), and \( Z = c-a \), we observe that \( X+Y+Z = (a-b)+(b-c)+(c-a) = 0 \). The identity, after being put over a common denominator, simplifies to verifying that \( -(X^2+Y^2+Z^2) = 2(XY+YZ+ZX) \), which is equivalent to \( X^2+Y^2+Z^2+2XY+2YZ+2ZX = 0 \). This is precisely \( (X+Y+Z)^2 = 0 \), which is true since \( X+Y+Z=0 \).

Thus, by systematically ensuring the validity of terms, performing field-level algebraic simplification, and then verifying the resulting polynomial identity, the equality is established.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 9. Prove that $\frac{b-c}{(a-b)(a-c)}+\frac{c-a}{(b-c)(b-a)}$ $+\frac{a-b}{(c-a)(c-b)}=\frac{2}{a-b}+\frac{2}{b-c}+\frac{2}{c-a}$. -/
theorem algebra_311369 {a b c : ℝ} (habc : a ≠ b ∧ a ≠ c ∧ b ≠ c) :
    (b - c) / ((a - b) * (a - c)) + (c - a) / ((b - c) * (b - a)) +
    (a - b) / ((c - a) * (c - b)) = 2 / (a - b) + 2 / (b - c) + 2 / (c - a) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_311369 {a b c : ℝ} (habc : a ≠ b ∧ a ≠ c ∧ b ≠ c) :
    (b - c) / ((a - b) * (a - c)) + (c - a) / ((b - c) * (b - a)) +
    (a - b) / ((c - a) * (c - b)) = 2 / (a - b) + 2 / (b - c) + 2 / (c - a) := by
  rcases habc with ⟨h1, h2, h3⟩
  have h4 : b - c ≠ 0 := by
    intro h
    apply h3
    linarith
  have h5 : a - b ≠ 0 := by
    intro h
    apply h1
    linarith
  have h6 : a - c ≠ 0 := by
    intro h
    apply h2
    linarith
  have h7 : b - a ≠ 0 := by
    intro h
    apply h1
    linarith
  have h8 : c - a ≠ 0 := by
    intro h
    apply h2
    linarith
  have h9 : c - b ≠ 0 := by
    intro h
    apply h3
    linarith
  field_simp [h5, h6, h4, h7, h8, h9]
  ring

informal_statement:
Given sequences $a_{n}$, $b_{n}$, and $x_{n}$ where $a_{n}$, $b_{n}$, $x_{n} > 0$ for all $n \in \mathbb{N}$, and the following conditions hold:
1. $\prod_{n=1}^{\infty}a_{n}=0$,
2. $\lim_{n\to\infty}\frac{b_{n}}{1-a_{n}}=0$,
3. $x_{n+1}\leq a_{n}x_{n}+b_{n}$ for all $n \in \mathbb{N}$.

Determine the value of $\lim_{n\to\infty}x_{n}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Topology Filter Real Complex TopologicalSpace Finset
open scoped BigOperators

/- Given sequences $a_{n}$, $b_{n}$, and $x_{n}$ where $a_{n}$, $b_{n}$, $x_{n} > 0$ for all $n \in \mathbb{N}$, and the following conditions hold:
1. $\prod_{n=1}^{\infty}a_{n}=0$,
2. $\lim_{n\to\infty}\frac{b_{n}}{1-a_{n}}=0$,
3. $x_{n+1}\leq a_{n}x_{n}+b_{n}$ for all $n \in \mathbb{N}$.

Determine the value of $\lim_{n\to\infty}x_{n}$. -/
theorem algebra_633
  (a b x : ℕ → ℝ)
  (h₀ : ∀ n, 0 < a n)
  (h₁ : ∀ n, 0 < b n)
  (h₂ : ∀ n, 0 < x n)
  (h₃ : Tendsto (λ n => ∏ i in range n, a i) atTop (𝓝 0))
  (h₄ : Tendsto (λ n => b n / (1 - a n)) atTop (𝓝 0))
  (h₅ : ∀ n, x (n + 1) ≤ a n * x n + b n) :
  ¬ ∃ L, Tendsto x atTop (𝓝 L) :=

$$\begin{array}{l}
\text { 21. }\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\sqrt{2 y^{2}+2 z^{2}} \geqslant y+z, \\
32\left(y^{2}+z^{2}\right)^{3}-(y+z)^{2}\left(5 y^{2}-2 y z+5 z^{2}\right)^{2} \\
=(y-z)^{4}\left(7 y^{2}-2 y z+7 z^{2}\right) \geqslant 0, \\
3 \sqrt{2 \prod_{\mathrm{cyc}}\left(y^{2}+z^{2}\right)}=\sqrt{6 \sum_{\mathrm{cyc}} x^{2}\left(3 y^{4}+2 y^{2} z^{2}+3 z^{4}\right)}
\end{array}\right. \\
\geqslant 2 \sqrt{3 \sum_{\text {cyc }} x^{2}\left(y^{2}+z^{2}\right)^{2}} \geqslant 2 \sum_{\text {cyc }} x\left(y^{2}+z^{2}\right), \\
\left(\sum_{\mathrm{cyc}} \sqrt{2\left(y^{2}+z^{2}\right)}\right)^{3}-\sum_{\mathrm{cyc}} 9(y+z)^{3} \\
=4 \sum_{\text {cyc }}\left(3 x^{2}+2 y^{2}+2 z^{2}\right) \sqrt{2 y^{2}+2 z^{2}}+12 \sqrt{2 \prod_{\text {cyc }}\left(y^{2}+z^{2}\right)} \\
-\sum_{\text {cyc }} 9(y+z)^{3} \\
\geqslant 12 \sum_{\text {cyc }} x^{2}(y+z)+2 \sum_{\text {cyc }}(y+z)\left(5 y^{2}-2 y z+5 z^{2}\right) \\
+8 \sum_{\text {cyc }} x\left(y^{2}+z^{2}\right)-\sum_{\text {cyc }} 9(y+z)^{3} \\
=2 \sum_{\text {cyc }} x^{3}-\sum_{\text {cyc }} x^{2}(y+z)=\sum_{\text {cyc }}(y+z)(y-z)^{2} \geqslant 0 .
\end{array}$$
informal_statement:
21. For non-negative real numbers $x, y, z$, prove:
$$\sum_{\text {cyc }} \sqrt{2\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)} \geqslant \sqrt[3]{9 \sum_{\text {cyc }}(x+y)^{3}} .$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- 21. For non-negative real numbers $x, y, z$, prove:
$$\sum_{\text {cyc }} \sqrt{2\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)} \geqslant \sqrt[3]{9 \sum_{\text {cyc }}(x+y)^{3}} .$$ -/
theorem inequalities_597517 (x y z : ℝ) (hx : 0 ≤ x) (hy : 0 ≤ y) (hz : 0 ≤ z) :
    sqrt (2 * (x^2 + y^2)) + sqrt (2 * (y^2 + z^2)) + sqrt (2 * (z^2 + x^2)) ≥
    (9 * (x + y)^3 + 9 * (y + z)^3 + 9 * (z + x)^3) ^ ((1 : ℝ) / 3) := by

soln_description:
15. Let $f(x)=a x+b+\frac{1}{x+1}$, then $f(1)+2 f(0)-3 f\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)=\frac{1}{2}+2-\frac{9}{4}=\frac{1}{4}$, we have
$$
\left.|f(1)|+2|f(0)|+3\left|f\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)^{\prime} \geqslant\right| f(1)+2 f(0)-3 f\left(\frac{1}{3}\right) \right\rvert\,=\frac{1}{4} \text {. }
$$

Therefore, $\left.f(1)|| f,(0)|| f,\left(\frac{1}{3}\right) \right\rvert\,$ must have at least one not less than $\frac{1}{24}$.
If $|f(1)|,|f(0)|,\left|f\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)\right|$ are all equal to $\frac{1}{24}$ (if one is less than $\frac{1}{24}$, then there must be one greater than $\frac{1}{24}$, the proposition is proved), then by the condition for equality in the inequality (1), it can only be

Only the former has a solution $(a, b)=\left(\frac{1}{2},-\frac{23}{24}\right)$. At this time, $f(x)=\frac{x}{2}+\frac{1}{x+1}-\frac{23}{24}$, since $\frac{x+1}{2}+\frac{1}{x+1} \geqslant \sqrt{2}$, equality is achieved when $x=\sqrt{2}-1$, so $\left.|f(\sqrt{2}-1)!=| \sqrt{2}-\frac{35}{24} \right\rvert\,=\frac{35}{24}-\sqrt{2}>\frac{1}{24}$. Thus, the proposition holds (the last inequality is due to $17^{2}>(12 \sqrt{2})^{2}$ ).
informal_statement: Proof: For any real numbers $a, b$ there exists a number $c \in [0,1]$, such that $\left|a c+b+\frac{1}{c+1}\right|>\frac{1}{24}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Proof: For any real numbers $a, b$ there exists a number $c \in [0,1]$, such that $\left|a c+b+\frac{1}{c+1}\right|>\frac{1}{24}$. -/
theorem inequalities_291815 (a b : ℝ) :
    ∃ c ∈ Set.Icc 0 1, |a * c + b + 1 / (c + 1)| > 1 / 24 := by
