informal_statement:
1. If the set $S=\{n \mid n$ is an integer, and $22 n+2$ divides $2003 n+2004\}$, then $S$ is
A. Empty set $\varnothing$
B. Singleton set
C. Set with two elements
D. Infinite set
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 1. If the set $S=\{n \mid n$ is an integer, and $22 n+2$ divides $2003 n+2004\}$, then $S$ is
A. Empty set $\varnothing$
B. Singleton set
C. Set with two elements
D. Infinite set -/
theorem number_theory_119018 :
    {n : ℤ | 22 * n + 2 ∣ 2003 * n + 2004}.encard = 2 := by

soln_description:
15. (i) If $p_{i} \mid a$, then $p_{i}^{a_{i}} \mid a^{a+q(m)}-a^{\alpha}$; if $p_{i} \nmid a$, then $p_{i}^{q_{i}} \mid a^{p\left(p_{i}^{\left.q_{i}\right)}\right.}-1$, hence $p_{i}^{q_{i}} \mid a^{\rho(m)}-1$. (ii) If $p_{i} \nmid a$, then by (i) we know $p_{i}^{g_{i}} \mid a^{\rho(m)}-1$, hence $p_{i}^{q_{i}} \mid a^{m-\rho(m)}\left(a^{\rho(m)}-1\right)=$ $a^{m}-a^{m-\varphi(m)}$; if $p_{i} \mid a$, by $m-\varphi(m) \geqslant p_{i}^{R_{i}-1} \geqslant \alpha_{i}$ (this can be derived from Exercise 2, Part 1, Question 18 or Equation (5) in §3), we also get $p_{i}^{q_{i}} \mid a^{m}-a^{m-\varphi(m)}$. (iii) This can be deduced from the discussion in (i). (iv) The original statement is equivalent to
$$a^{1+A_{j}\left(p_{j}-1\right)} \equiv a\left(\bmod p_{j}\right), \quad 1 \leqslant j \leqslant r$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 15. Let \( m = p_{1}^{q_{1}} \cdots p_{r}^{q_{r}}, p_{j} \) be different primes,
\[ c_{j} = \varphi\left(p_{j}^{q_{j}}\right), \quad \alpha = \max \left(\alpha_{1}, \cdots, \alpha_{r}\right) \]

Prove: For any integer \( a \) we have
(i) \( a^{a + \varphi(m)} \equiv a^{\alpha} \pmod{m} \);
(ii) \( a^{m} \equiv a^{m - \varphi(m)} \pmod{m} \);
(iii) \( a^{a} f(a) \equiv 0 \pmod{m} \), where \( f(x) \) is the least common multiple of the polynomials \( x^{c_{1}} - 1, \cdots, x^{c_{r}} - 1 \), explain the meaning of this problem;
(iv) If \( \alpha_{1} = \cdots = \alpha_{r} = 1 \), then we must have
\[ a^{1 + \varphi(m)} \equiv a \pmod{m} \] -/
theorem number_theory_6228 {m : ℕ} (hm : m ≠ 0) (p : Finset ℕ)
    (hp : ∀ i ∈ p, Nat.Prime i) (q : ℕ → ℕ) (hq : ∀ i ∈ p, q i > 0)
    (α : ℕ) (hα : α = sSup {q i | i ∈ p}) :
    ∀ a : ℕ, a ^ (a + m.totient) ≡ a ^ α [ZMOD m] ∧
    a ^ m ≡ a ^ (m - m.totient) [ZMOD m] ∧
    ∃ f : ℕ, f = sInf {x | ∀ i ∈ p, x ∣ (i ^ (q i) - 1)} ∧
    a ^ a * f ≡ 0 [ZMOD m] ∧
    (α = 1 → a ^ (1 + m.totient) ≡ a [ZMOD m]) := by

soln_description:
27. Given that $a^{n}+1$ is a prime number, we know that $a$ is even. Similar to problem 6, there exists a non-negative integer $k$ such that $n=2^{k}$. Therefore,
$$\begin{aligned}
& a^{n}-1 \\
= & a^{2^{k}}-1 \\
= & \left(a^{2^{k-1}}-1\right)\left(a^{2^{k-1}}+1\right) \\
= & \cdots \\
= & (a-1)(a+1)\left(a^{2}+1\right) \cdots\left(a^{2^{k-1}}+1\right)
\end{aligned}$$

Furthermore, $\left(a^{2^{k-1}}-1, a^{2^{k-1}}+1\right)=\left(a^{2^{k-1}}-1,2\right)=1$ (the last step uses the fact that $a$ is even). Tracing back, we know that $a+1, a^{2}+1, a^{2^{2}}+1, \cdots, a^{2^{k-1}}+1$ are pairwise coprime. Thus, any product of these numbers forms $2^{k}$ distinct numbers, and these $2^{k}$ numbers are all divisors of $a^{n}-1$. Therefore, $d\left(a^{n}-1\right) \geqslant 2^{k}=n$.
informal_statement: 27 Let $a, n$ be positive integers, $a>1$, and $a^{n}+1$ is a prime. Prove: $d\left(a^{n}-1\right) \geqslant n$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 27 Let $a, n$ be positive integers, $a>1$, and $a^{n}+1$ is a prime. Prove: $d\left(a^{n}-1\right) \geqslant n$.

 -/
theorem number_theory_7895 (a n : ℕ) (ha : 1 < a) (hn : 0 < n)
    (h : Nat.Prime (a ^ n + 1)) :
    (a ^ n - 1).divisors.card ≥ n := by

soln_description:
First, we provide two lemmas.

Lemma 1 The positive integer solutions of the Pell equation $\left|p^{2}-2 q^{2}\right|=1$ are
$$
p=b_{n}, q=a_{n}\left(n \in \mathbf{Z}_{+}\right),
$$

where $b_{1}=1, b_{2}=3, b_{k+2}=2 b_{k+1}+b_{k}(k \geqslant 1)$.
Lemma 2 The positive integer solutions of the Pell equation $\left|p^{2}-2 q^{2}\right|=2$ are $p=2 a_{n}, q=b_{n}\left(n \in \mathbf{Z}_{+}\right)$.
Both lemmas can be proven using the basic solution method of Pell equations.
It is not difficult to calculate that
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\lim _{n \rightarrow+\infty} a_{n}^{2}\left|\frac{b_{n}}{a_{n}}-\sqrt{2}\right|=\lim _{n \rightarrow+\infty}\left|a_{n} b_{n}-\sqrt{2} a_{n}^{2}\right| \\
=\lim _{n \rightarrow+\infty} \frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}+\sqrt{2} a_{n}}=\frac{\sqrt{2}}{4} .
\end{array}
$$

Thus, we conjecture that $\beta$ in (1) is all real numbers not less than $\frac{\sqrt{2}}{4}$. In fact,
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\left|\frac{p}{q}-\sqrt{2}\right|1)
$$
$\Leftrightarrow p=2 a_{n}, q=b_{n}$ ( $n$ is an odd positive integer greater than 1).
According to the limit expression, we know that when $01$ the smallest term occurs when $n=3$. At this time,
$$
\beta=70-49 \sqrt{2} \text {. }
$$

Therefore, the range of $\beta$ is $\left(70-49 \sqrt{2}, \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\right)$.
informal_statement:
Define the sequence of positive integers $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ as
$$
a_{1}=1, a_{2}=2, a_{k+2}=2 a_{k+1}+a_{k}(k \geqslant 1) \text {. }
$$
(1) Find all positive real numbers $\beta$ such that there are infinitely many pairs of positive integers $(p, q)$ satisfying
$$
\left|\frac{p}{q}-\sqrt{2}\right|<\frac{\beta}{q^{2}} ;
$$
(2) Find all positive real numbers $\beta$ such that there are only finitely many pairs of positive integers $(p, q)$ satisfying
$$
\left|\frac{p}{q}-\sqrt{2}\right|<\frac{\beta}{q^{2}},
$$
and there does not exist any $n$ such that $q=a_{n}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

def a : ℕ → ℕ
| 0 => 1
| 1 => 2
| n + 2 => 2 * a (n + 1) + a n

/- Define the sequence of positive integers $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ as
$$
a_{1}=1, a_{2}=2, a_{k+2}=2 a_{k+1}+a_{k}(k \geqslant 1) \text {. }
$$
(1) Find all positive real numbers $\beta$ such that there are infinitely many pairs of positive integers $(p, q)$ satisfying
$$
\left|\frac{p}{q}-\sqrt{2}\right|<\frac{\beta}{q^{2}} ;
$$
(2) Find all positive real numbers $\beta$ such that there are only finitely many pairs of positive integers $(p, q)$ satisfying
$$
\left|\frac{p}{q}-\sqrt{2}\right|<\frac{\beta}{q^{2}},
$$
and there does not exist any $n$ such that $q=a_{n}$. -/
theorem number_theory_328436 :
    {β : ℝ | 0 < β ∧ {p : ℕ | ∃ q : ℕ, 0 < p ∧ 0 < q ∧ |(p / q : ℝ) - sqrt 2| < β / q ^ 2}.Infinite} =
    {β | 70 - 49 * sqrt 2 < β ∧ β < sqrt 2 / 2} ∧
    {β : ℝ | 0 < β ∧ {p : ℕ | ∃ q : ℕ, 0 < p ∧ 0 < q ∧ |(p / q : ℝ) - sqrt 2| < β / q ^ 2}.Finite ∧
      ¬∃ n : ℕ, q = a n} =
    {β | 70 - 49 * sqrt 2 < β ∧ β < sqrt 2 / 2} := by

soln_description: Solution: If $x \leq 0.7$ and $y \leq 0.7$, then $x+y \leq 1.4$ and $\frac{1}{x+y} \geq \frac{1}{1.4}>0.7$.
informal_statement: 9.1 If $x$ and $y$ are positive numbers, then at least one of the numbers $x$, $y$, and $\frac{1}{x+y}$ is greater than 0.7. Prove this.
informal_proof:
Let \(x\) and \(y\) be positive real numbers, i.e., \(x > 0\) and \(y > 0\). We want to prove that at least one of the following inequalities holds: \(x > 0.7\), \(y > 0.7\), or \(1/(x+y) > 0.7\). We proceed by a series of case analyses.

**Case 1: \(x > 0.7\)**
If \(x > 0.7\), then the first condition of the disjunction is true. Therefore, the entire disjunction holds.

**Case 2: \(x \leq 0.7\)**
Since the first condition (\(x > 0.7\)) is false, we must have \(x \leq 0.7\). We now consider a subcase for \(y\).

  **Subcase 2.1: \(y > 0.7\)**
  If \(y > 0.7\), then the second condition of the disjunction is true. Therefore, the entire disjunction holds.

  **Subcase 2.2: \(y \leq 0.7\)**
  Since both \(x \leq 0.7\) and \(y \leq 0.7\) (and we also know \(x > 0\) and \(y > 0\) from the given hypotheses), we can derive some properties about their sum:
  
  1.  From \(x \leq 0.7\) and \(y \leq 0.7\), it follows that \(x + y \leq 0.7 + 0.7\), which simplifies to \(x + y \leq 1.4\).
  2.  From \(x > 0\) and \(y > 0\), it follows that \(x + y > 0\).

  Now we perform a further subcase analysis based on the value of \(x+y\).

    **Subcase 2.2.1: \(x + y = 1.4\)**
    If \(x + y = 1.4\), then we can calculate the value of \(1/(x+y)\):
    \[
    \frac{1}{x+y} = \frac{1}{1.4}
    \]
    Numerically, \(1/1.4 = 1/(14/10) = 10/14 = 5/7\).
    We check if \(5/7 > 0.7\). Since \(0.7 = 7/10\), we are comparing \(5/7\) with \(7/10\).
    To compare, we find a common denominator: \(5/7 = 50/70\) and \(7/10 = 49/70\).
    Clearly, \(50/70 > 49/70\), so \(5/7 > 0.7\).
    Therefore, the third condition \(1/(x+y) > 0.7\) holds.

    **Subcase 2.2.2: \(x + y \neq 1.4\)**
    We know from earlier that \(x + y \leq 1.4\). Since we are in the case where \(x + y \neq 1.4\), it must be that \(x + y < 1.4\). This can be formally shown by contradiction: if we assume \(x + y \geq 1.4\), then combining with \(x + y \leq 1.4\) implies \(x + y = 1.4\), which contradicts our assumption for this subcase.
    
    So, we have \(x + y < 1.4\). Combining this with \(x + y > 0\) (derived earlier), we have \(0 < x + y < 1.4\).
    
    Now, we use the property that for positive real numbers \(a\) and \(b\), if \(a < b\), then \(1/b < 1/a\). Applying this to \(0 < x + y < 1.4\), we get:
    \[
    \frac{1}{x+y} > \frac{1}{1.4}
    \]
    As shown in Subcase 2.2.1, we know that \(1/1.4 = 5/7\), and \(5/7 > 0.7\).
    Therefore, by transitivity, \(1/(x+y) > 1/1.4 > 0.7\), which implies \(1/(x+y) > 0.7\).
    Thus, the third condition \(1/(x+y) > 0.7\) holds.

In every possible case, at least one of the three conditions \(x > 0.7\), \(y > 0.7\), or \(1/(x+y) > 0.7\) is satisfied. This completes the proof.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 9.1 If $x$ and $y$ are positive numbers, then at least one of the numbers $x$, $y$, and $\frac{1}{x+y}$ is greater than 0.7. Prove this. -/
theorem inequalities_289689 (x y : ℝ) (hx : 0 < x) (hy : 0 < y) :
    x > 0.7 ∨ y > 0.7 ∨ (1 / (x + y)) > 0.7 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem inequalities_289689 (x y : ℝ) (hx : 0 < x) (hy : 0 < y) :
    x > 0.7 ∨ y > 0.7 ∨ (1 / (x + y)) > 0.7 := by

  by_cases h1 : x > 0.7 
  · -- Assume x > 0.7
    left 
    exact h1 
  · -- Assume x ≤ 0.7
    by_cases h2 : y > 0.7 
    · -- Assume y > 0.7 
      right 
      left 
      exact h2 
    · -- Assume y ≤ 0.7 
      have h3 : x ≤ 0.7 := by linarith 
      have h4 : y ≤ 0.7 := by linarith 
      have h5 : x + y ≤ (0.7 : ℝ) + (0.7 : ℝ) := by linarith 
      have h6 : x + y > 0 := by linarith 
      by_cases h7 : x + y = 1.4 
      · -- When x + y = 1.4 
        have h8 : 1 / (x + y) = 5 / 7 := by 
          rw [h7]
          norm_num 
        right 
        right 
        rw [h8]
        norm_num 
      · -- When x + y ≠ 1.4 
        have h8 : x + y < (1.4 : ℝ) := by 
          by_contra h 
          push_neg at h 
          have h9 : x + y = (1.4 : ℝ) := by 
            linarith 
          trivial 
        have h9 : 1 / (x + y) > 1 / (1.4 : ℝ) := by 
          apply one_div_lt_one_div_of_lt 
          all_goals 
            nlinarith 
        have h10 : (1 / (1.4 : ℝ) : ℝ) > 0.7 := by norm_num 
        right 
        right 
        linarith

soln_description: For any $i$, we have $0 \leq\left(x_{i}+1\right)\left(x_{i}-2\right)^{2}=x_{i}^{3}-3 x_{i}^{2}+4$. Adding all of these we deduce that $\sum_{i=1}^{n} x_{i}^{2} \leq \frac{1}{3} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(x_{i}^{3}+4\right)=\frac{4}{3} n$. Equality occurs, for example, when $n=9, x_{1}=\cdots=x_{8}=-1$ and $x_{9}=2$. Therefore, the answer is $\frac{4}{3}$.
informal_statement:
Find, with proof, the largest possible value of

$$
\frac{x_{1}^{2}+\cdots+x_{n}^{2}}{n}
$$

where real numbers $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n} \geq-1$ are satisfying $x_{1}^{3}+\cdots+x_{n}^{3}=0$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- Find, with proof, the largest possible value of

$$
\frac{x_{1}^{2}+\cdots+x_{n}^{2}}{n}
$$

where real numbers $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n} \geq-1$ are satisfying $x_{1}^{3}+\cdots+x_{n}^{3}=0$. -/
theorem algebra_256184 {n : ℕ} (hn : 0 < n) :
    IsGreatest {t : ℝ | ∃ x : Fin n → ℝ, (∀ i, -1 ≤ x i) ∧ (∑ i, x i ^ 3) = 0 ∧ t = (∑ i, x i ^ 2) / n} (n / 2) := by

soln_description:
1. We denote by $v_{a}$ the initial velocity, by $v_{e}$ the final velocity, and by $v_{d}$ the average velocity of the aircraft during rolling. Furthermore, let $l$ be the rolling distance and $t$ the required time. It holds that $\frac{v_{a}+v_{e}}{2}=v_{d}$. Given $v_{a}=0 \frac{\mathrm{m}}{\mathrm{s}}, v_{e} \approx 44.4 \frac{\mathrm{m}}{\mathrm{s}}$, we obtain $v_{d} \approx 22.2 \frac{\mathrm{m}}{\mathrm{s}}$.
2. For the rolling distance $l$, it holds that: $l=v_{d} \cdot t \approx 666 \, \text{m} \approx \frac{2}{3} \, \text{km}$.
3. For the acceleration $a$, it holds that: $a=\frac{v_{e}-v_{a}}{t} \approx 1.48 \frac{\mathrm{m}}{\mathrm{s}^{2}}$.
4. According to the fundamental law of dynamics, the force $F$ is calculated as $F=m \cdot a$. For the mass $m$, it holds that $m=\frac{G}{g}$, where $G$ is the weight and $g=9.81 \frac{\mathrm{m}}{\mathrm{s}^{2}}$ is the acceleration due to gravity.

Then, $F=\frac{G \cdot a}{g} \approx 2720 \, \text{kp}$.

5. Work $W=F \cdot l \approx 1810000 \, \text{kpm}$.
6. Power $P=\frac{W}{t} \approx 60000 \, \frac{\text{kpm}}{\text{s}}$. This corresponds to 800 HP, so that each engine must deliver about 400 HP.
informal_statement:
## Task 17/61

The passenger aircraft IL 14 P of Deutsche Lufthansa weighs approximately $18000 \mathrm{kp}$ including full payload. It requires about 30 s from the start of rolling until it takes off from the ground and has a speed of around $160 \frac{\mathrm{km}}{\mathrm{h}}$ at the moment of takeoff.

For the following calculations, neglect friction and air resistance and consider the motion of the aircraft as uniformly accelerated.

1. What is the average speed during rolling?
2. What is the rolling distance?
3. What is the acceleration of the aircraft?
4. What force is necessary to produce this acceleration?
5. What work is done by the two engines during rolling for the acceleration?
6. What power (in PS) must each of the two engines provide?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- ## Task 17/61

The passenger aircraft IL 14 P of Deutsche Lufthansa weighs approximately $18000 \mathrm{kp}$ including full payload. It requires about 30 s from the start of rolling until it takes off from the ground and has a speed of around $160 \frac{\mathrm{km}}{\mathrm{h}}$ at the moment of takeoff.

For the following calculations, neglect friction and air resistance and consider the motion of the aircraft as uniformly accelerated.

1. What is the average speed during rolling?
2. What is the rolling distance?
3. What is the acceleration of the aircraft?
4. What force is necessary to produce this acceleration?
5. What work is done by the two engines during rolling for the acceleration?
6. What power (in PS) must each of the two engines provide? -/
theorem algebra_144911 (v : ℝ) (h : v = 160) (s : ℝ) (hs : s = 30) :
    v * s / 2 = 400 := by

soln_description:
Solution: From the given, we have
$$
a^{3}+b^{3}+(-1)^{3}-3 a b(-1)=0 \text {. }
$$

By the formula
$$
\begin{array}{l}
a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}-3 a b c \\
=(a+b+c)\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}-a b-b c-a c\right),
\end{array}
$$

if $a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}-3 a b c=0$, then $a+b+c=0$ or $a=b=c$.

Therefore, $a+b+(-1)=0$ or $a=b=-1$. Hence, $a+b=1$ or $a+b=-2$.
informal_statement:
Question 3 Given real numbers $a, b$ satisfy $a^{3}+b^{3}+3 a b=1$. Find $a+b$.
(2004, National Junior High School Mathematics League)
informal_proof:
Let \(a\) and \(b\) be real numbers satisfying the given condition \(a^3 + b^3 + 3ab = 1\). We want to show that \(a+b=1\) or \(a+b=-2\).

**Step 1: Reformulate the Hypothesis using an Algebraic Identity**
We begin by rearranging the given equation \(a^3 + b^3 + 3ab = 1\) to resemble a standard algebraic identity.
We know the identity: \(x^3 + y^3 + z^3 - 3xyz = (x+y+z)(x^2+y^2+z^2-xy-yz-zx)\).
Let \(x=a\), \(y=b\), and \(z=-1\). Substituting these into the identity, we get:
\(a^3 + b^3 + (-1)^3 - 3ab(-1) = (a+b-1)(a^2+b^2+(-1)^2 - ab - b(-1) - (-1)a)\).
Simplifying both sides:
\(a^3 + b^3 - 1 + 3ab = (a+b-1)(a^2+b^2+1 - ab + b + a)\).
The left side \(a^3 + b^3 - 1 + 3ab\) is exactly \(0\) due to the given hypothesis \(a^3 + b^3 + 3ab = 1\).
So, we have:
\(0 = (a+b-1)(a^2+b^2+1 - ab + b + a)\).

**Step 2: Further Factorization of the Second Term**
Let's simplify the second factor \(a^2+b^2+1 - ab + b + a\). We can use the identity \(a^2+b^2 = (a+b)^2 - 2ab\).
Substituting this into the second factor:
\((a+b)^2 - 2ab + 1 - ab + b + a\)
\(= (a+b)^2 + (a+b) + 1 - 3ab\).
Thus, the equation from Step 1 becomes:
\((a+b-1)((a+b)^2 + (a+b) + 1 - 3ab) = 0\).
This is the critical intermediate step in the Lean proof, established by the `nlinarith` tactic.

**Step 3: Case Analysis using the Zero Product Property**
Since the product of two real numbers is zero if and only if at least one of the numbers is zero, we can split this into two cases:

**Case 1: The first factor is zero.**
\(a+b-1 = 0\).
This directly implies \(a+b = 1\).
This matches the first disjunct of our goal.

**Case 2: The second factor is zero.**
\((a+b)^2 + (a+b) + 1 - 3ab = 0\).
Let's expand and rearrange this expression:
\(a^2 + 2ab + b^2 + a + b + 1 - 3ab = 0\)
\(a^2 + b^2 - ab + a + b + 1 = 0\).
To reveal a sum of squares, we can multiply the entire equation by 2:
\(2a^2 + 2b^2 - 2ab + 2a + 2b + 2 = 0\).
Now, we can group terms to form perfect squares:
\((a^2 - 2ab + b^2) + (a^2 + 2a + 1) + (b^2 + 2b + 1) = 0\).
This simplifies to:
\((a-b)^2 + (a+1)^2 + (b+1)^2 = 0\).
Since \(a, b\) are real numbers, their squares are non-negative. For a sum of non-negative terms to be zero, each term must individually be zero.
Therefore:
1.  \((a-b)^2 = 0 \implies a-b=0 \implies a=b\).
2.  \((a+1)^2 = 0 \implies a+1=0 \implies a=-1\).
3.  \((b+1)^2 = 0 \implies b+1=0 \implies b=-1\).
From these three conditions, we deduce that \(a=-1\) and \(b=-1\).
Consequently, \(a+b = (-1) + (-1) = -2\).
This matches the second disjunct of our goal. This deduction is performed by the `nlinarith` tactic using the algebraic information.

**Conclusion:**
In Case 1, we found \(a+b=1\). In Case 2, we found \(a+b=-2\). Since these are the only two possibilities arising from the factorization of the original equation, we conclude that if \(a^3 + b^3 + 3ab = 1\), then \(a+b=1\) or \(a+b=-2\).

The proof is complete.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Question 3 Given real numbers $a, b$ satisfy $a^{3}+b^{3}+3 a b=1$. Find $a+b$.
(2004, National Junior High School Mathematics League) -/
theorem algebra_315642 {a b : ℝ} (h : a^3 + b^3 + 3 * a * b = 1) :
    a + b = 1 ∨ a + b = -2 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_315642 {a b : ℝ} (h : a^3 + b^3 + 3 * a * b = 1) :
    a + b = 1 ∨ a + b = -2 := by
  have h1 : (a + b - 1) * ((a + b)^2 + (a + b) + 1 - 3 * a * b) = 0 := by 
    nlinarith [sq_nonneg (a - b), sq_nonneg (a + b - 1), sq_nonneg (a + b + 2)]
  cases' (mul_eq_zero.mp h1) with h2 h3
  · -- Case where $a + b = 1$
    left
    linarith 
  · -- Case where $(a + b)^2 + (a + b) + 1 - 3ab = 0$
    right
    nlinarith [sq_nonneg (a - b), sq_nonneg (a + b + 2), sq_nonneg (a * b - 1)]

informal_statement: If the eccentricity of the hyperbola $\Gamma_{1}: \frac{x^{2}}{a^{2}}- \frac{y^{2}}{b^{2}}=1(a$, $b>0)$ is $3$, then the eccentricity of the hyperbola $\Gamma_{2}: \frac{y^{2}}{b^{2}}- \frac{x^{2}}{a^{2}}=1$ is ___          ___ .
informal_proof:
Let $a$ and $b$ be positive real numbers. We are given the eccentricity of the hyperbola $\Gamma_1: \frac{x^2}{a^2} - \frac{y^2}{b^2} = 1$ as $3$. The formula for the eccentricity of this type of hyperbola is $\sqrt{1 + \frac{b^2}{a^2}}$. Therefore, we have the initial condition:
$$ \sqrt{1 + \frac{b^2}{a^2}} = 3 $$

Our goal is to find the eccentricity of the hyperbola $\Gamma_2: \frac{y^2}{b^2} - \frac{x^2}{a^2} = 1$. The formula for the eccentricity of this type of hyperbola (where the $y^2$ term is positive) is $\sqrt{1 + \frac{a^2}{b^2}}$.

We proceed with the following steps:

1.  **Square the initial condition**: Since $a, b > 0$, we know that $1 + \frac{b^2}{a^2} > 0$. We can square both sides of the initial condition to remove the square root:
    $$ \left(\sqrt{1 + \frac{b^2}{a^2}}\right)^2 = 3^2 $$
    This simplifies to:
    $$ 1 + \frac{b^2}{a^2} = 9 $$

2.  **Isolate the ratio $\frac{b^2}{a^2}$**: Subtract $1$ from both sides of the equation:
    $$ \frac{b^2}{a^2} = 9 - 1 $$
    $$ \frac{b^2}{a^2} = 8 $$

3.  **Find the relationship between $a^2$ and $b^2$**: From the previous step, we can multiply both sides by $a^2$ (which is non-zero since $a > 0$):
    $$ b^2 = 8a^2 $$

4.  **Calculate the reciprocal ratio $\frac{a^2}{b^2}$**: We need $\frac{a^2}{b^2}$ for the eccentricity of $\Gamma_2$. Using the relationship $b^2 = 8a^2$:
    $$ \frac{a^2}{b^2} = \frac{a^2}{8a^2} $$
    Since $a > 0$, $a^2 \neq 0$, so we can cancel $a^2$ from the numerator and denominator:
    $$ \frac{a^2}{b^2} = \frac{1}{8} $$

5.  **Calculate the argument of the square root for $\Gamma_2$'s eccentricity**: Now, substitute the value of $\frac{a^2}{b^2}$ into the expression $1 + \frac{a^2}{b^2}$:
    $$ 1 + \frac{a^2}{b^2} = 1 + \frac{1}{8} $$
    $$ 1 + \frac{a^2}{b^2} = \frac{8}{8} + \frac{1}{8} = \frac{9}{8} $$

6.  **Compute the eccentricity of $\Gamma_2$**: Finally, we take the square root of this value:
    $$ \sqrt{1 + \frac{a^2}{b^2}} = \sqrt{\frac{9}{8}} $$
    To simplify this expression, we can write it as:
    $$ \sqrt{\frac{9}{8}} = \frac{\sqrt{9}}{\sqrt{8}} = \frac{3}{\sqrt{4 \cdot 2}} = \frac{3}{2\sqrt{2}} $$
    To rationalize the denominator, multiply the numerator and denominator by $\sqrt{2}$:
    $$ \frac{3}{2\sqrt{2}} \cdot \frac{\sqrt{2}}{\sqrt{2}} = \frac{3\sqrt{2}}{2 \cdot 2} = \frac{3\sqrt{2}}{4} $$

Therefore, the eccentricity of the hyperbola $\Gamma_2$ is $\frac{3\sqrt{2}}{4}$.

The final answer is $\boxed{\frac{3\sqrt{2}}{4}}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- If the eccentricity of the hyperbola $\Gamma_{1}: \frac{x^{2}}{a^{2}}- \frac{y^{2}}{b^{2}}=1(a$, $b>0)$ is $3$, then the eccentricity of the hyperbola $\Gamma_{2}: \frac{y^{2}}{b^{2}}- \frac{x^{2}}{a^{2}}=1$ is ___          ___. -/
/- If the eccentricity of the hyperbola $\Gamma_{1}: \frac{x^{2}}{a^{2}}- \frac{y^{2}}{b^{2}}=1(a$, $b>0)$ is $3$, then the eccentricity of the hyperbola $\Gamma_{2}: \frac{y^{2}}{b^{2}}- \frac{x^{2}}{a^{2}}=1$ is ___          ___ . -/
theorem algebra_8548 {a b : ℝ} (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b)
    (h : √(1 + b^2 / a^2) = 3) :
    √(1 + a^2 / b^2) = 3 * √2 / 4 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

/- If the eccentricity of the hyperbola $\Gamma_{1}: \frac{x^{2}}{a^{2}}- \frac{y^{2}}{b^{2}}=1(a$, $b>0)$ is $3$, then the eccentricity of the hyperbola $\Gamma_{2}: \frac{y^{2}}{b^{2}}- \frac{x^{2}}{a^{2}}=1$ is ___          ___. -/
theorem algebra_8548 {a b : ℝ} (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b)
    (h : √(1 + b^2 / a^2) = 3) :
    √(1 + a^2 / b^2) = 3 * √2 / 4 := by 
  have h1 : 1 + b ^ 2 / a ^ 2 = 9 := by
    calc
      1 + b ^ 2 / a ^ 2 = (√(1 + b ^ 2 / a ^ 2)) ^ 2 := by rw [Real.sq_sqrt]; positivity
      _ = 3 ^ 2 := by rw [h]
      _ = 9 := by norm_num
  have h2 : b ^ 2 = 8 * a ^ 2 := by 
    field_simp [ha.ne.symm] at h1 ⊢
    nlinarith
  have h3 : a ^ 2 / b ^ 2 = 1 / 8 := by 
    rw [show b ^ 2 = 8 * a ^ 2 by linarith [h2]]
    field_simp [ha.ne.symm]
    <;> nlinarith
  have h4 : 1 + a ^ 2 / b ^ 2 = 9 / 8 := by 
    rw [h3]
    <;> field_simp <;> ring
  calc
    √(1 + a^2 / b^2) = √(9 / 8) := by rw [h4]
    _ = 3 * √2 / 4 := by
      rw [Real.sqrt_eq_iff_sq_eq] <;> norm_num
      <;> ring_nf <;> norm_num
      <;> ring_nf <;> norm_num

import Mathlib

/- The maximum value of the function $f(x)=\sqrt{x-5}+\sqrt{24-3x}$ is (   ).

A: $\sqrt{3}$

B: $3$

C: $2\sqrt{3}$

D: $3\sqrt{3}$ -/
theorem algebra_12416 : IsGreatest {x | ∃ t, x = sqrt (t - 5) + sqrt (24 - 3 * t)} (2 * sqrt 3) := by

soln_description:
To determine the number of digits in the smallest repunit that is divisible by \(97\), we need to find the smallest integer \(n\) such that the repunit \(R_n\) (which consists of \(n\) digits all being \(1\)) is divisible by \(97\).

A repunit \(R_n\) can be expressed as:
\[ R_n = \frac{10^n - 1}{9} \]

We need \(R_n\) to be divisible by \(97\), which means:
\[ \frac{10^n - 1}{9} \equiv 0 \pmod{97} \]

This implies:
\[ 10^n - 1 \equiv 0 \pmod{97} \]
\[ 10^n \equiv 1 \pmod{97} \]

We are looking for the smallest positive integer \(n\) such that \(10^n \equiv 1 \pmod{97}\). This \(n\) is known as the order of \(10\) modulo \(97\).

By Fermat's Little Theorem, since \(97\) is a prime number, we know:
\[ 10^{96} \equiv 1 \pmod{97} \]

This tells us that \(10^n \equiv 1 \pmod{97}\) for some \(n\) that divides \(96\). We need to find the smallest such \(n\).

To do this, we check the divisors of \(96\) (which are \(1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, 12, 16, 24, 32, 48, 96\)) to find the smallest \(n\) for which \(10^n \equiv 1 \pmod{97}\).

1. \(10^1 \equiv 10 \pmod{97}\) (not \(1\))
2. \(10^2 \equiv 100 \equiv 3 \pmod{97}\) (not \(1\))
3. \(10^3 \equiv 10 \cdot 3 \equiv 30 \pmod{97}\) (not \(1\))
4. \(10^4 \equiv 10 \cdot 30 \equiv 300 \equiv 9 \pmod{97}\) (not \(1\))
5. \(10^6 \equiv 10^2 \cdot 10^4 \equiv 3 \cdot 9 \equiv 27 \pmod{97}\) (not \(1\))
6. \(10^8 \equiv 10^4 \cdot 10^4 \equiv 9 \cdot 9 \equiv 81 \pmod{97}\) (not \(1\))
7. \(10^{12} \equiv 10^8 \cdot 10^4 \equiv 81 \cdot 9 \equiv 729 \equiv 51 \pmod{97}\) (not \(1\))
8. \(10^{16} \equiv 10^8 \cdot 10^8 \equiv 81 \cdot 81 \equiv 6561 \equiv 64 \pmod{97}\) (not \(1\))
9. \(10^{24} \equiv 10^{16} \cdot 10^8 \equiv 64 \cdot 81 \equiv 5184 \equiv 43 \pmod{97}\) (not \(1\))
10. \(10^{32} \equiv 10^{16} \cdot 10^{16} \equiv 64 \cdot 64 \equiv 4096 \equiv 21 \pmod{97}\) (not \(1\))
11. \(10^{48} \equiv 10^{24} \cdot 10^{24} \equiv 43 \cdot 43 \equiv 1849 \equiv 3 \pmod{97}\) (not \(1\))
12. \(10^{96} \equiv 1 \pmod{97}\) (this is \(1\))

Since \(10^{96} \equiv 1 \pmod{97}\) and no smaller \(n\) satisfies this condition, the smallest \(n\) is \(96\).

Conclusion:
\(\boxed{96}\)
informal_statement:
Jerry's favorite number is $97$.  He knows all kinds of interesting facts about $97$:

[list][*]$97$ is the largest two-digit prime.
[*]Reversing the order of its digits results in another prime.
[*]There is only one way in which $97$ can be written as a difference of two perfect squares.
[*]There is only one way in which $97$ can be written as a sum of two perfect squares. 
[*]$\tfrac1{97}$ has exactly $96$ digits in the [smallest] repeating block of its decimal expansion.
[*]Jerry blames the sock gnomes for the theft of exactly $97$ of his socks.[/list]

A repunit is a natural number whose digits are all $1$.  For instance, \begin{align*}&1,\\&11,\\&111,\\&1111,\\&\vdots\end{align*} are the four smallest repunits.  How many digits are there in the smallest repunit that is divisible by $97?$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Jerry's favorite number is $97$.  He knows all kinds of interesting facts about $97$:

[list][*]$97$ is the largest two-digit prime.
[*]Reversing the order of its digits results in another prime.
[*]There is only one way in which $97$ can be written as a difference of two perfect squares.
[*]There is only one way in which $97$ can be written as a sum of two perfect squares. 
[*]$\tfrac1{97}$ has exactly $96$ digits in the [smallest] repeating block of its decimal expansion.
[*]Jerry blames the sock gnomes for the theft of exactly $97$ of his socks.[/list]

A repunit is a natural number whose digits are all $1$.  For instance, \begin{align*}&1,\\&11,\\&111,\\&1111,\\&\vdots\end{align*} are the four smallest repunits.  How many digits are there in the smallest repunit that is divisible by $97?$ -/
theorem number_theory_66240 : IsLeast {n | 97 ∣ (Nat.ofDigits 10 (List.replicate n 1))} 96 := by

informal_statement: If the sum of positive integers $m$ and $n$ is $32$, and their least common multiple is $x$. Find the difference between the minimum and maximum possible values of $x$.
formal_statement:

/- If the sum of positive integers $m$ and $n$ is $32$, and their least common multiple is $x$. Find the difference between the minimum and maximum possible values of $x$.

 -/
/- If the sum of positive integers $m$ and $n$ is $32$, and their least common multiple is $x$. Find the difference between the minimum and maximum possible values of $x$.


 -/
theorem number_theory_5945 :
    IsLeast {x : ℕ | ∃ m n, m > 0 ∧ n > 0 ∧ m + n = 32 ∧ Nat.lcm m n = x} 1 ∧
    IsGreatest {x : ℕ | ∃ m n, m > 0 ∧ n > 0 ∧ m + n = 32 ∧ Nat.lcm m n = x} 239 := by

/- 73. Seven monkeys share a box of chestnuts, each getting a different amount, with the monkey that gets the most receiving 50 nuts. Therefore, the box of chestnuts can have at most $\qquad$ nuts. -/
theorem number_theory_119783 (x : Fin 7 → ℕ) (hx : ∀ i, x i > 0) (hxi : ∀ i j, x i = x j → i = j)

    ∑ i, x i ≤ 329 := by

soln_description:
This problem was posed at the Asia Pacific Olympiad in 2016. If \( f(a) = f(b) \) for two real numbers \( a \) and \( b \), by substituting \( z \) with \( a \) and then with \( b \), we get \((a+1) f(x+y) = (b+1) f(x+y)\). Since \( f \) is strictly positive, we deduce \( a = b \). Thus, \( f \) is injective.

By setting \( x = y \), we obtain \( f(x f(z) + x) = \frac{z+1}{2} f(2x) \). Let \( s \) be in the image of \( f \), denoted by \(\operatorname{Im}(f)\). For any real number \( r > 1 / 2 \), \( s r \) is also in the image of \( f \), so \( ] s / 2, +\infty[ \subset \operatorname{Im}(f) \). For any \( u > s / 4 \), there exists \( r > 1 / 2 \) such that \( u / r > s / 2 \), so the same reasoning guarantees that \( u \in \operatorname{Im}(f) \), hence \( ] s / 4, +\infty[ \subset \operatorname{Im}(f) \). Continuing this process, we get \( ] s / 2^n, +\infty[ \subset \operatorname{Im}(f) \) for all \( n \in \mathbb{N}^{*} \). For any strictly positive real number \( r \), there exists \( n_r \in \mathbb{N} \) such that \( r > s / 2^{n_r} \), so \( r \in \operatorname{Im}(f) \). Finally, \(\operatorname{Im}(f) = \mathbb{R}_{+}^{*} \), and \( f \) is surjective.

Therefore, \( f \) is bijective.

Next, an idea is to prove that for all \( a, b, c, d \) such that \( a + b = c + d \), we have \( f(a) + f(b) = f(c) + f(d) \), by setting \( x = a, y = b \) (or vice versa) in the equation, and then \( x = c, y = d \). If we find \( z \) such that

\[
\{a f(z) + b, b f(z) + a\} = \{c f(z) + d, d f(z) + c\}
\]

we are done. Therefore, we need to study this system, using the surjectivity of \( f \). This opens up many possibilities for substitutions to finish the exercise. For more details, see here.
informal_statement:
(APMO 2016)

Find all functions $f: \mathbb{R}_{+}^{*} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{+}^{*}$ such that

$$
(z+1) f(x+y)=f(x f(z)+y)+f(y f(z)+x)
$$

for all $x, y, z>0$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- (APMO 2016)

Find all functions $f: \mathbb{R}_{+}^{*} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{+}^{*}$ such that

$$
(z+1) f(x+y)=f(x f(z)+y)+f(y f(z)+x)
$$

for all $x, y, z>0$. -/
theorem algebra_157825 (f : ℝ → ℝ) (hf : ∀ x > 0, f x > 0)
    (h : ∀ x y z, (z + 1) * f (x + y) = f (x * f z + y) + f (y * f z + x)) :
    ∃ c, ∀ x > 0, f x = c * x := by

soln_description:
2. (a) Setting $a=n c$ and $b=n d$ we see that $\frac{a^{3}+2 b^{3}}{c^{3}+2 d^{3}}=n^{3}$ is special for all $n \in \mathbb{N}$.

(b) Suppose that $2014=\frac{a^{3}+2 b^{3}}{c^{3}+2 d^{3}}$, i.e. $a^{3}+2 b^{3}=2 \cdot 19 \cdot 53\left(c^{3}+2 d^{3}\right)$. We can assume w.l.o.g. that $\operatorname{gcd}(a, b, c, d)=1$. The possible residues of cubes modulo 19 are $0, \pm 1, \pm 7, \pm 8$, so $a^{3} \equiv 2 b^{3}$ can hold only if $19 \mid a, b$. However, this implies $19^{3} \mid a^{3}+2 b^{3}$ and thus $19^{2} \mid c^{3}+2 d^{3}$, so we also deduce $19 \mid c, d$, a contradiction.
informal_statement:
2. A special number is a positive integer $n$ for which there exist positive integers $a, b, c$ and $d$ with

$$
n=\frac{a^{3}+2 b^{3}}{c^{3}+2 d^{3}}
$$

Prove that:

(a) there are infinitely many special numbers;

(b) 2014 is not a special number.

(Romania)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 2. A special number is a positive integer $n$ for which there exist positive integers $a, b, c$ and $d$ with

$$
n=\frac{a^{3}+2 b^{3}}{c^{3}+2 d^{3}}
$$

Prove that:

(a) there are infinitely many special numbers;

(b) 2014 is not a special number.

(Romania) -/
theorem number_theory_128868 :
    (∀ N : ℕ, ∃ n : ℕ, n > N ∧ ∃ a b c d : ℕ, a > 0 ∧ b > 0 ∧ c > 0 ∧ d > 0 ∧ n = (a^3 + 2 * b^3) / (c^3 + 2 * d^3)) ∧
    ¬∃ n : ℕ, n = 2014 ∧ ∃ a b c d : ℕ, a > 0 ∧ b > 0 ∧ c > 0 ∧ d > 0 ∧ n = (a^3 + 2 * b^3) / (c^3 + 2 * d^3) := by

soln_description:
[Solution] In the identity given in the problem, let $x=y=0$ to get $f(0)=2 f(0)$, which means $f(0)=0$. For any $x \in \mathbb{R}$, from the identity
$$f(x+y)-f(x) \equiv f(y)+2 x y, \quad y \in \mathbb{R}$$

we get
$$\begin{aligned}
f^{\prime}(x) & =\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{f(x+y)-f(x)}{y} \equiv \lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{f(y)+2 x y}{y} \\
& =2 x+\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{f(y)-f(0)}{y}=2 x+f^{\prime}(0)
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the function we seek satisfies
$$f(x)=f(x)-f(0)=\int_{0}^{x} f^{\prime}(x) d x=x^{2}+f^{\prime}(0) x$$

Note that, for each $a \in \mathbb{R}$, the function $f(x)=x^{2}+a x$ satisfies the identity given in the problem.
informal_statement:
6. 144 Find all infinitely differentiable functions \( f: R \rightarrow R \) that satisfy
$$f(x+y) \equiv f(x)+f(y)+2 x y, x, y \in R$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 6. 144 Find all infinitely differentiable functions \( f: R \rightarrow R \) that satisfy
$$f(x+y) \equiv f(x)+f(y)+2 x y, x, y \in R$$ -/
theorem algebra_601344 (f : ℝ → ℝ) (hf : ∀ x y, f (x + y) = f x + f y + 2 * x * y)
    (hfdiff : ContDiff ℝ ⊤ f) :
    ∃ a, ∀ x, f x = x ^ 2 + a * x := by

soln_description:
To solve the problem, we need to find all positive integers \( n \) such that the expression 

\[
\frac{n(n+2016)(n+2 \cdot 2016)(n+3 \cdot 2016) \cdots (n+2015 \cdot 2016)}{1 \cdot 2 \cdot 3 \cdots 2016}
\]

is a positive integer. Let's denote the numerator and the denominator separately for clarity:

Numerator: \( n(n+2016)(n+2 \cdot 2016)(n+3 \cdot 2016) \cdots (n+2015 \cdot 2016) \)

Denominator: \( 1 \cdot 2 \cdot 3 \cdots 2016 = 2016! \)

We need the fraction \(\frac{n(n+2016)(n+2 \cdot 2016) \cdots (n+2015 \cdot 2016)}{2016!}\) to be an integer. This means that the numerator must be divisible by \(2016!\).

1. **Prime Factorization of 2016:**
   \[
   2016 = 2^5 \cdot 3^2 \cdot 7
   \]

2. **Divisibility Condition:**
   For the fraction to be an integer, the numerator must contain at least the same number of each prime factor as the denominator. Therefore, we need to ensure that the numerator has at least 5 factors of 2, 2 factors of 3, and 1 factor of 7.

3. **Considering Prime Factors:**
   - For \( p = 2 \):
     The sequence \( n, n+2016, n+2 \cdot 2016, \ldots, n+2015 \cdot 2016 \) must collectively contain at least 5 factors of 2.
   - For \( p = 3 \):
     The sequence must collectively contain at least 2 factors of 3.
   - For \( p = 7 \):
     The sequence must collectively contain at least 1 factor of 7.

4. **Ensuring Divisibility:**
   To ensure that the sequence contains the required number of factors of each prime, \( n \) must be divisible by the least common multiple (LCM) of the prime factors' requirements. The LCM of 2, 3, and 7 is 42.

5. **Conclusion:**
   Therefore, \( n \) must be divisible by 42. Any positive integer \( n \) that is a multiple of 42 will satisfy the condition.

\[
\boxed{n = 42k \text{ for any positive integer } k}
\]
informal_statement:
find all positive integer $n$, satisfying
$$\frac{n(n+2016)(n+2\cdot 2016)(n+3\cdot 2016) . . . (n+2015\cdot 2016)}{1\cdot 2 \cdot 3 \cdot . . . . . \cdot 2016}$$ is positive integer.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- find all positive integer $n$, satisfying
$$\frac{n(n+2016)(n+2\cdot 2016)(n+3\cdot 2016) . . . (n+2015\cdot 2016)}{1\cdot 2 \cdot 3 \cdot . . . . . \cdot 2016}$$ is positive integer. -/
theorem number_theory_45417 {n : ℕ} (hn : n > 0) :
    ∃ k, n = 42 * k := by

soln_description:
41. Clearly, $2 j+1=(j+1)^{2}-j^{2}$, thus, by the AM-GM inequality, we have
$$\begin{array}{l}
\sum_{j=1}^{n} \frac{2 j+1}{j^{2}}=\sum_{j=1}^{n}\left[\frac{(j+1)^{2}}{j^{2}}-1\right]=\sum_{j=1}^{n} \frac{(j+1)^{2}}{j^{2}}-n> \\
\sqrt[n]{\frac{2^{2}}{1^{2}} \cdot \frac{3^{2}}{2^{2}} \cdots \cdot \frac{(n+1)^{2}}{n^{2}}}-n=n \sqrt[n]{\frac{1}{n^{2}}}-n
\end{array}$$
(because $\frac{2^{2}}{1^{2}} \frac{3^{2}}{2^{2}}, \cdots, \frac{(n+1)^{2}}{n^{2}}$ are pairwise unequal, hence $\left.A_{n}>G_{n}\right)$, the left inequality is proved. For the second inequality, it is easy to see that
$$\begin{array}{l}
n+4-\sum_{j=1}^{n} \frac{2 j+1}{j^{2}}=4+\sum_{j=1}^{n}\left(1-\frac{2 j+1}{j^{2}}\right)= \\
4+\sum_{j=1}^{n} \frac{(j-1)^{2}-2}{j^{2}}=4+\sum_{j=1}^{n} \frac{(j-1)^{2}}{j^{2}}-2 \sum_{j=1}^{n} \frac{1}{j^{2}}
\end{array}$$

Introducing an undetermined positive constant $k$
$$\begin{array}{l}
\sum_{j=1}^{n} \frac{(j-1)^{2}}{j^{2}}=\left(\frac{1}{4}-k\right)+\left(k+\frac{2^{2}}{3^{2}}+\frac{3^{2}}{4^{2}}+\cdots+\frac{(n-1)^{2}}{n^{2}}\right)> \\
\left(\frac{1}{4}-k\right)+(n-1)\left(k \cdot \frac{2^{2}}{3^{2}} \cdot \frac{3^{2}}{4^{2}} \cdots \cdot \frac{(n-1)^{2}}{n^{2}}\right)^{1 /(n-1)}= \\
\left(\frac{1}{4}-k\right)+(n-1)(4 k)^{1 /(n-1)} n^{-2 /(n-1)}
\end{array}$$

Thus,
$$k=\frac{1}{4}\left(\frac{n}{n-1}\right)^{n-1}(\text { for positive integer } n>1)$$

Substituting (4) and (5) into (3), we get
$$\sum_{j=1}^{n} \frac{(j-1)^{2}}{j^{2}}>\frac{1}{4}-\frac{1}{4}\left(\frac{n}{n-1}\right)^{n-1}+n \cdot n^{-2(n-1)}$$

It is not difficult to prove using the binomial theorem that
$$\left(\frac{n}{n-1}\right)^{n}=\left(1+\frac{1}{n-1}\right)^{n-1}1)$$

Substituting (6) and (7) into (2), we get
$$n+4-\sum_{j=1}^{n} \frac{2 j+1}{j^{2}}>n \cdot n^{-2 /(n-1)}+\frac{7}{2}-2 \sum_{j=1}^{n} \frac{1}{j^{2}}$$

And
$$\begin{array}{l}
\sum_{j=1}^{n} \frac{1}{j^{2}}=1+\frac{1}{4}+\frac{1}{3^{2}}+\frac{1}{4^{2}}+\frac{1}{5^{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{n^{2}}n \cdot n^{-2 /(n-1)}
\end{array}$$
informal_statement:
41. For each positive integer $n>1$, prove the inequality:
$$n\left[(n+1)^{\frac{2}{n}}-1\right]<\sum_{j=1}^{n} \frac{2 j+1}{j^{2}}<n\left(1-n^{-\frac{2}{n-1}}\right)+4$$
(1994 British Mathematical Olympiad)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- 41. For each positive integer $n>1$, prove the inequality:
$$n\left[(n+1)^{\frac{2}{n}}-1\right]<\sum_{j=1}^{n} \frac{2 j+1}{j^{2}}<n\left(1-n^{-\frac{2}{n-1}}\right)+4$$
(1994 British Mathematical Olympiad) -/
theorem inequalities_603088 (n : ℕ) (hn : 1 < n) :
    n * ((n + 1) ^ (2 / n : ℝ) - 1) < ∑ j in Finset.Icc 1 n, (2 * j + 1) / (j ^ 2 : ℝ) ∧
    ∑ j in Finset.Icc 1 n, (2 * j + 1) / (j ^ 2 : ℝ) < n * (1 - n ^ (-2 / (n - 1 : ℝ)) : ℝ) + 4 := by

soln_description:
If after a few years the mother will be four times as old as Margit, the grandmother will be twice as old as the mother.

The age difference of 32 years between the grandmother and the mother does not change. It will therefore also be 32 at the later time mentioned in the problem. At that time, however, since the grandmother will be twice the age of the mother, it will be equal to the mother's age at that time. She will then be 32 years old, which will happen in two years. Since $32 \div 4 = 8$, Margit will be 8 years old at that time; therefore, she is now 6 years old.
informal_statement:
## Task 3 - 180713

How old is Margit now if her mother is currently 30 years old, her grandmother is currently 62 years old, and in a few years the mother will be four times as old and at the same time the grandmother will be eight times as old as Margit?

(Only full years of life are considered.)
informal_proof:
Let `margit_age` be Margit's current age, and let `x` be the number of years that pass until the stated conditions hold. We are given that `margit_age` and `x` are positive natural numbers.

We are given the following information:
1.  Margit's mother's current age is 30 years: `mother_age = 30`.
2.  Margit's grandmother's current age is 62 years: `grandmother_age = 62`.
3.  In `x` years, the mother's age will be four times Margit's age: `mother_age + x = 4 * (margit_age + x)`.
4.  In `x` years, the grandmother's age will be eight times Margit's age: `grandmother_age + x = 8 * (margit_age + x)`.

Our goal is to find `margit_age`.

First, substitute the known current ages of the mother and grandmother into the equations describing their future ages:

The mother's age equation becomes:
`30 + x = 4 * (margit_age + x)` (Equation 1)

The grandmother's age equation becomes:
`62 + x = 8 * (margit_age + x)` (Equation 2)

Now, we expand and rearrange these equations:

From Equation 1:
`30 + x = 4 * margit_age + 4 * x`
Subtract `x` from both sides:
`30 = 4 * margit_age + 3 * x` (Equation 1')

From Equation 2:
`62 + x = 8 * margit_age + 8 * x`
Subtract `x` from both sides:
`62 = 8 * margit_age + 7 * x` (Equation 2')

We now have a system of two linear equations with two unknowns (`margit_age` and `x`):
1.  `4 * margit_age + 3 * x = 30`
2.  `8 * margit_age + 7 * x = 62`

To solve this system, we can use the method of elimination. Multiply Equation 1' by 2:
`2 * (4 * margit_age + 3 * x) = 2 * 30`
`8 * margit_age + 6 * x = 60` (Equation 3)

Now, subtract Equation 3 from Equation 2':
`(8 * margit_age + 7 * x) - (8 * margit_age + 6 * x) = 62 - 60`
` (8 * margit_age - 8 * margit_age) + (7 * x - 6 * x) = 2`
`x = 2`

This result tells us that "a few years" refers to exactly 2 years. This satisfies the condition `x > 0`.

Now, substitute `x = 2` back into Equation 1':
`4 * margit_age + 3 * (2) = 30`
`4 * margit_age + 6 = 30`
Subtract `6` from both sides:
`4 * margit_age = 24`
Divide by `4`:
`margit_age = 6`

This result also satisfies the condition `margit_age > 0`.

Therefore, Margit's current age is 6 years.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- ## Task 3 - 180713

How old is Margit now if her mother is currently 30 years old, her grandmother is currently 62 years old, and in a few years the mother will be four times as old and at the same time the grandmother will be eight times as old as Margit?

(Only full years of life are considered.) -/
theorem algebra_169606 (margit_age : ℕ) (h : margit_age > 0) (mother_age grandmother_age : ℕ)
    (h_mother : mother_age = 30) (h_grandmother : grandmother_age = 62) (x : ℕ)
    (hx : x > 0) (h_mother_in_x : mother_age + x = 4 * (margit_age + x)) (h_grandmother_in_x : grandmother_age + x = 8 * (margit_age + x)) :
    margit_age = 6 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_169606 (margit_age : ℕ) (h : margit_age > 0) (mother_age grandmother_age : ℕ)
    (h_mother : mother_age = 30) (h_grandmother : grandmother_age = 62) (x : ℕ)
    (hx : x > 0) (h_mother_in_x : mother_age + x = 4 * (margit_age + x)) (h_grandmother_in_x : grandmother_age + x = 8 * (margit_age + x)) :
    margit_age = 6 := by 
  subst h_mother
  subst h_grandmother
  omega

soln_description:
Answer: 25 km/h or 5 km/h.

Solution. Let's draw a numerical axis along the highway, taking the starting point of the cyclists as the origin and directing it in the direction of the second cyclist's movement. His speed is 10 km/h, so after an hour, he was at point B with a coordinate of 10. The distance from him to the first cyclist is 20 km, which means the first cyclist was at point $\mathrm{A}_{1}$ with a coordinate of 30 (if he was moving in the same direction as the second) or at point $A_{2}$ with a coordinate of -10 (if he was moving in the opposite direction). Let's determine the coordinate of the third cyclist. The distance between him and the first cyclist was 5 km. However, since his speed is lower, he could not have moved further from the starting point. Therefore, in the first case, he was at point $\mathrm{C}_{1}$ with a coordinate of $30-5=25$, and in the second case, at point $C_{2}$ with a coordinate of $-10+5=-5$. Accordingly, in the first case, his speed is 25 km/h (and all cyclists are moving in the same direction), and in the second case, his speed is 5 km/h (and the direction of movement of the 1st and 3rd cyclists is opposite to the direction of the 2nd cyclist).

Criteria. Only the answer (if both options are specified) - 1 point. If only one case is considered in the solution - no more than 3 points.
informal_statement: 2. From one point on a straight highway, three cyclists start simultaneously (but possibly in different directions). Each of them rides at a constant speed without changing direction. An hour after the start, the distance between the first and second cyclist was 20 km, and the distance between the first and third - 5 km. At what speed is the third cyclist riding, if it is known that he is riding slower than the first, and the speed of the second is 10 km/h? List all possible options.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 2. From one point on a straight highway, three cyclists start simultaneously (but possibly in different directions). Each of them rides at a constant speed without changing direction. An hour after the start, the distance between the first and second cyclist was 20 km, and the distance between the first and third - 5 km. At what speed is the third cyclist riding, if it is known that he is riding slower than the first, and the speed of the second is 10 km/h? List all possible options. -/
theorem algebra_158136 (v1 v2 v3 : ℝ) (h : v1 > 0) (h' : v2 > 0) (h'' : v3 > 0)
    (h''' : v2 = 10) (h'''' : |v1 - v2| = 20) (h''''' : |v1 - v3| = 5) :
    v3 = 25 := by

informal_statement: There is a four-digit integer. By adding a decimal point in front of one of its digits and then adding this to the four-digit number, the result is $2000.81$. Find this four-digit number.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- There is a four-digit integer. By adding a decimal point in front of one of its digits and then adding this to the four-digit number, the result is $2000.81$. Find this four-digit number. -/
theorem algebra_592 (x d : ℕ) (hx₁ : x < 10) (hx₂ : x > 0) (h : (10 * x + d) * 10 + x = 2000 + 81) :
    d = 9 ∧ x = 1 := by

soln_description:
$\triangle$ Let's use the characteristic properties of arithmetic and geometric progressions:

$$
\left\{\begin{array} { l } 
{ 1 = \frac { a + b } { 2 } , } \\
{ 1 = \sqrt { a ^ { 2 } b ^ { 2 } } , }
\end{array} \quad \left\{\begin{array}{l}
a+b=2 \\
a^{2} b^{2}=1
\end{array}\right.\right.
$$

It remains to solve the last system of equations.

Answer: $a=b=1 ; \quad a=1+\sqrt{2}, b=1-\sqrt{2} ; \quad a=1-\sqrt{2}, b=1+\sqrt{2}$.
informal_statement: 256. Find the numbers $a$ and $b$, if the numbers $a, 1, b$ form an arithmetic progression, and the numbers $a^{2}, 1, b^{2}$ form a geometric progression. List all solutions.
informal_proof:
We are given two conditions:
1.  The numbers \(a, 1, b\) form an arithmetic progression.
2.  The numbers \(a^2, 1, b^2\) form a geometric progression.

Let's translate these conditions into algebraic equations.

**Step 1: Extracting information from the arithmetic progression condition.**
The first condition implies that there exists a common difference \(d\) such that:
\(a + d = 1\) (let's call this (1.1))
\(1 + d = b\) (let's call this (1.2))

From (1.1), we can express \(d\) as \(d = 1 - a\).
Substituting this into (1.2), we get \(1 + (1 - a) = b\), which simplifies to \(2 - a = b\).
Thus, we establish our first key relationship:
**Equation (A): \(b = 2 - a\)**

**Step 2: Extracting information from the geometric progression condition.**
The second condition implies that there exists a common ratio \(r\) such that:
\(a^2 \cdot r = 1\) (let's call this (2.1))
\(1 \cdot r = b^2\) (let's call this (2.2))

From (2.2), we directly have \(r = b^2\).
Substituting this into (2.1), we get \(a^2 \cdot b^2 = 1\).
Thus, we establish our second key relationship:
**Equation (G): \(a^2 b^2 = 1\)**

**Step 3: Solving the system of equations.**
We now have a system of two equations:
1.  \(b = 2 - a\)
2.  \(a^2 b^2 = 1\)

First, let's analyze Equation (G). Since \(a^2 b^2 = (ab)^2\), we have \((ab)^2 = 1\).
This implies that \(ab\) must be either \(1\) or \(-1\).
So, we have two main cases:
**Case 1: \(ab = 1\)**
**Case 2: \(ab = -1\)**

**Case 1: \(ab = 1\)**
Substitute \(b = 2 - a\) (from Equation (A)) into \(ab = 1\):
\(a(2 - a) = 1\)
\(2a - a^2 = 1\)
Rearranging gives \(a^2 - 2a + 1 = 0\).
This is a perfect square: \((a - 1)^2 = 0\).
Taking the square root of both sides, we get \(a - 1 = 0\), which implies \(a = 1\).

Now, substitute \(a = 1\) back into Equation (A), \(b = 2 - a\):
\(b = 2 - 1\)
\(b = 1\)
So, the first solution is \((a, b) = (1, 1)\).

**Case 2: \(ab = -1\)**
Substitute \(b = 2 - a\) (from Equation (A)) into \(ab = -1\):
\(a(2 - a) = -1\)
\(2a - a^2 = -1\)
Rearranging gives \(a^2 - 2a - 1 = 0\).
We can solve this quadratic equation for \(a\) using the quadratic formula \(a = \frac{-B \pm \sqrt{B^2 - 4AC}}{2A}\), where \(A=1, B=-2, C=-1\):
\(a = \frac{-(-2) \pm \sqrt{(-2)^2 - 4(1)(-1)}}{2(1)}\)
\(a = \frac{2 \pm \sqrt{4 + 4}}{2}\)
\(a = \frac{2 \pm \sqrt{8}}{2}\)
\(a = \frac{2 \pm 2\sqrt{2}}{2}\)
\(a = 1 \pm \sqrt{2}\)

This leads to two sub-cases for \(a\):

**Subcase 2.1: \(a = 1 + \sqrt{2}\)**
Substitute this value of \(a\) back into Equation (A), \(b = 2 - a\):
\(b = 2 - (1 + \sqrt{2})\)
\(b = 2 - 1 - \sqrt{2}\)
\(b = 1 - \sqrt{2}\)
So, the second solution is \((a, b) = (1 + \sqrt{2}, 1 - \sqrt{2})\).

**Subcase 2.2: \(a = 1 - \sqrt{2}\)**
Substitute this value of \(a\) back into Equation (A), \(b = 2 - a\):
\(b = 2 - (1 - \sqrt{2})\)
\(b = 2 - 1 + \sqrt{2}\)
\(b = 1 + \sqrt{2}\)
So, the third solution is \((a, b) = (1 - \sqrt{2}, 1 + \sqrt{2})\).

**Conclusion:**
Combining all the solutions found from the cases, the possible pairs \((a, b)\) are:
1.  \(a = 1\) and \(b = 1\)
2.  \(a = 1 + \sqrt{2}\) and \(b = 1 - \sqrt{2}\)
3.  \(a = 1 - \sqrt{2}\) and \(b = 1 + \sqrt{2}\)

These are precisely the three stated solutions, completing the proof.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 256. Find the numbers $a$ and $b$, if the numbers $a, 1, b$ form an arithmetic progression, and the numbers $a^{2}, 1, b^{2}$ form a geometric progression. List all solutions. -/
theorem algebra_187940 {a b : ℝ} (h1 : ∃ d, a + d = 1 ∧ 1 + d = b) (h2 : ∃ r, a^2 * r = 1 ∧ 1 * r = b^2) :
    a = 1 ∧ b = 1 ∨ a = 1 + Real.sqrt 2 ∧ b = 1 - Real.sqrt 2 ∨ a = 1 - Real.sqrt 2 ∧ b = 1 + Real.sqrt 2 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_187940 {a b : ℝ} (h1 : ∃ d, a + d = 1 ∧ 1 + d = b) (h2 : ∃ r, a^2 * r = 1 ∧ 1 * r = b^2) :
    a = 1 ∧ b = 1 ∨ a = 1 + Real.sqrt 2 ∧ b = 1 - Real.sqrt 2 ∨ a = 1 - Real.sqrt 2 ∧ b = 1 + Real.sqrt 2 := by
  rcases h1 with ⟨d, h11, h12⟩
  rcases h2 with ⟨r, h21, h22⟩
  have h3 : b = 2 - a := by
    linarith

  have h4 : a ^ 2 * b ^ 2 = 1 := by
    have hr : r = b^2 := by linarith
    rw [hr] at h21
    nlinarith
  
  have h5 : a * b = 1 ∨ a * b = -1 := by 
    have h6 : (a * b) ^ 2 = 1 := by
      nlinarith [h4]
    have h8 : (a * b) ^ 2 - 1 = 0 := by 
      nlinarith 
    have h9 : (a * b - 1) * (a * b + 1) = 0 := by 
      nlinarith 
    cases (mul_eq_zero.mp h9) with
    | inl h10 =>
      left 
      linarith 
    | inr h11 =>
      right 
      linarith 
  cases h5 with
  | inl h51 =>
    have h6 : a = 1 := by
      rw [show b = 2 - a by linarith [h3]] at h51
      nlinarith [sq_nonneg (a - 1)]
    have h7 : b = 1 := by
      rw [h6] at h3
      linarith
    left 
    exact ⟨h6, h7⟩
  | inr h52 =>
    have h7 : a^2 - 2*a - 1 = 0 := by
      rw [show b = 2 - a by linarith [h3]] at h52
      nlinarith
    have h8 : a = 1 + Real.sqrt 2 ∨ a = 1 - Real.sqrt 2 := by 
      have h9 : a^2 - 2 * a - 1 = 0 := h7
      have h10 : (a - (1 + Real.sqrt 2)) * (a - (1 - Real.sqrt 2)) = 0 := by
        nlinarith [Real.sqrt_pos.mpr (show (0:ℝ) < (2:ℝ) by norm_num : (2:ℝ) > 0), Real.sq_sqrt (show (0:ℝ) ≤ 2 by norm_num : (2:ℝ) ≥ 0)]
      cases (mul_eq_zero.mp h10) with
      | inl h11 =>
        left 
        linarith 
      | inr h12 =>
        right 
        linarith 
    cases h8 with
    | inl ha1 =>
      have hb1 : b = 1 - Real.sqrt 2 := by
        rw [show b = 2 - a by linarith [h3]]
        rw [ha1]
        ring
      right 
      left 
      exact ⟨ha1, hb1⟩
    | inr ha2 =>
      have hb2 : b = 1 + Real.sqrt 2 := by
        rw [show b = 2 - a by linarith [h3]]
        rw [ha2]
        ring
      right 
      right 
      exact ⟨ha2, hb2⟩

soln_description:
[Solution] Let's assume that A, B, and C can complete the work alone in $x$ days, $y$ days, and $z$ days, respectively. According to the problem, we have
$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\frac{1}{x}+\frac{1}{y}=\frac{1}{2} \\
\frac{1}{y}+\frac{1}{z}=\frac{1}{4} \\
\frac{1}{z}+\frac{1}{x}=\frac{1}{2.4} .
\end{array}\right.
$$
$\left.\frac{1}{2}(1)+(2)+(3)\right)$ gives $\frac{1}{x}+\frac{1}{y}+\frac{1}{z}=\frac{7}{12}$,
(4) - (2) gives $\frac{1}{x}=\frac{4}{12}=\frac{1}{3}$.
$$
\therefore \quad x=3 \text {. }
$$

Therefore, the answer is $(B)$.
informal_statement:
$3 \cdot 41$ To complete a certain task, A and B working together need 2 days; B and C working together need 4 days; C and A working together need 2.4 days. Then the number of days A needs to complete the task alone is
(A) 2.8 .
(B) 3 .
(C) 6 .
(D) 12 .
(China Junior High School Mathematics Correspondence Competition, 1988)
informal_proof:
We are given three real numbers, \(a\), \(b\), and \(c\), representing the time taken by individuals A, B, and C respectively, to complete a certain task alone. The conditions \(0 < a\), \(0 < b\), and \(0 < c\) state that these times are positive. We are also provided with three equations relating their combined work rates:
1.  \(1 / (a + b) = 2\)
2.  \(1 / (b + c) = 4\)
3.  \(1 / (c + a) = 2.4\)

Our goal is to determine the value of \(1/a\).

**Step 1: Justifying Non-Zero Denominators**

First, we need to ensure that the denominators in the given equations are non-zero to justify inverting them.
*   Since \(a > 0\) and \(b > 0\), their sum \(a + b\) must be strictly positive, i.e., \(a + b > 0\). This implies \(a + b \neq 0\). (If we were to assume \(a+b=0\), then equation (1) would become \(1/0 = 2\), which is a contradiction.)
*   Similarly, since \(b > 0\) and \(c > 0\), it follows that \(b + c > 0\), which implies \(b + c \neq 0\).
*   Likewise, since \(c > 0\) and \(a > 0\), it follows that \(c + a > 0\), which implies \(c + a \neq 0\).

**Step 2: Rewriting the Given Equations**

Now that we have established that the denominators are non-zero, we can invert the given equations:
*   From equation (1), \(1 / (a + b) = 2\), by inverting both sides, we get:
    (4) \(a + b = 1 / 2\)
*   From equation (2), \(1 / (b + c) = 4\), by inverting both sides, we get:
    (5) \(b + c = 1 / 4\)
*   From equation (3), \(1 / (c + a) = 2.4\), by inverting both sides, we get \(c + a = 1 / 2.4\). We convert the decimal to a fraction: \(2.4 = 24/10 = 12/5\). Therefore, \(1 / 2.4 = 1 / (12/5) = 5/12\). So:
    (6) \(c + a = 5 / 12\)

**Step 3: Solving for \(a\)**

We now have a system of three linear equations:
(4) \(a + b = 1/2\)
(5) \(b + c = 1/4\)
(6) \(c + a = 5/12\)

To solve for \(a\), we can use a standard algebraic method. Add equations (4), (5), and (6) together:
\((a + b) + (b + c) + (c + a) = 1/2 + 1/4 + 5/12\)
Combining like terms on the left side:
\(2a + 2b + 2c = 1/2 + 1/4 + 5/12\)
To sum the fractions on the right side, we find a common denominator, which is 12:
\(2a + 2b + 2c = 6/12 + 3/12 + 5/12\)
\(2(a + b + c) = (6 + 3 + 5) / 12\)
\(2(a + b + c) = 14 / 12\)
\(2(a + b + c) = 7 / 6\)
Dividing by 2, we get:
(7) \(a + b + c = 7 / 12\)

Now, to find \(a\), we subtract equation (5) from equation (7):
\((a + b + c) - (b + c) = 7/12 - 1/4\)
\(a = 7/12 - 3/12\) (since \(1/4 = 3/12\))
\(a = (7 - 3) / 12\)
\(a = 4 / 12\)
\(a = 1 / 3\)

**Step 4: Final Calculation**

We have found that \(a = 1/3\). The problem asks for the value of \(1/a\).
Substituting the value of \(a\):
\(1 / a = 1 / (1/3)\)
\(1 / a = 3\)

Therefore, the number of days A needs to complete the task alone is 3.

The final answer is \(\boxed{3}\).
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- $3 \cdot 41$ To complete a certain task, A and B working together need 2 days; B and C working together need 4 days; C and A working together need 2.4 days. Then the number of days A needs to complete the task alone is
(A) 2.8 .
(B) 3 .
(C) 6 .
(D) 12 .
(China Junior High School Mathematics Correspondence Competition, 1988) -/
theorem algebra_269269 (a b c : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c)
    (h1 : 1 / (a + b) = 2) (h2 : 1 / (b + c) = 4) (h3 : 1 / (c + a) = 2.4) :
    1 / a = 3 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_269269 (a b c : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c)
    (h1 : 1 / (a + b) = 2) (h2 : 1 / (b + c) = 4) (h3 : 1 / (c + a) = 2.4) :
    1 / a = 3 := by 
  have eq1 : a + b ≠ 0 := by
    by_contra h
    have h4 : a + b = 0 := by linarith
    rw [h4] at h1
    norm_num at h1

  have eq2 : b + c ≠ 0 := by 
    by_contra h
    have h4 : b + c = 0 := by linarith
    rw [h4] at h2
    norm_num at h2
  
  have eq3 : c + a ≠ 0 := by
    by_contra h
    have h4 : c + a = 0 := by linarith
    rw [h4] at h3
    norm_num at h3

  have eq4 : a + b = 1 / 2 := by 
    have h5 : 1 / (a + b) = 2 := h1
    field_simp [eq1] at h5 ⊢
    linarith
  
  have eq5 : b + c = 1 / 4 := by 
    have h6 : 1 / (b + c) = 4 := h2
    field_simp [eq2] at h6 ⊢
    linarith
  
  have eq6 : c + a = 5 / 12 := by 
    have h7 : 1 / (c + a) = 2.4 := h3
    field_simp [eq3] at h7 ⊢
    ring_nf at h7 ⊢
    linarith
  
  have h_a : a = 1 / 3 := by
    linarith

  have h4 : 1 / a = 3 := by
    rw [h_a]
    norm_num
  
  exact h4

soln_description:
Answer:
By the condition, we know that $|P(x)-Q(x)| \leq 1$ for all $x$. This can only hold if $P(x)-Q(x)$ is a constant polynomial. Now take a constant $c$ such that $P(x)=Q(x)+c$. Without loss of generality, we can assume that $c \geq 0$. Assume that $c>0$. By continuity, if $\operatorname{deg} P=\operatorname{deg} Q>0$, we can select an integer $r$ and a real number $x_{0}$ such that $Q\left(x_{0}\right)+c=r$. Then $\left\lfloor P\left(x_{0}\right)\right\rfloor=\left\lfloor Q\left(x_{0}\right)+c\right\rfloor=r$. On the other hand, $\left\lfloor Q\left(x_{0}\right)\right\rfloor=\lfloor r-c\rfloor<r$ as $r$ was an integer. This is a contradiction. Therefore, $c=0$ as desired.
informal_statement:
1. [15] Let $P(x), Q(x)$ be nonconstant polynomials with real number coefficients. Prove that if
$$
\lfloor P(y)\rfloor=\lfloor Q(y)\rfloor
$$
for all real numbers $y$, then $P(x)=Q(x)$ for all real numbers $x$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 1. [15] Let $P(x), Q(x)$ be nonconstant polynomials with real number coefficients. Prove that if
$$
\lfloor P(y)\rfloor=\lfloor Q(y)\rfloor
$$
for all real numbers $y$, then $P(x)=Q(x)$ for all real numbers $x$. -/
theorem algebra_168547 {P Q : Polynomial ℝ} (hP : P.degree > 0) (hQ : Q.degree > 0)
    (h : ∀ y : ℝ, ⌊P.eval y⌋ = ⌊Q.eval y⌋) : ∀ x : ℝ, P.eval x = Q.eval x := by

soln_description:
7.18. We will prove the statement by induction on $n \in \mathbf{N}$. Since

$$
\left(1-x_{1}\right)^{m}+\left(1-y_{1}^{m}\right)=y_{1}^{m}+\left(1-y_{1}^{m}\right)=1
$$

the statement is true for $n=1$. Suppose it is true for the number $n-1$, then we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(1-x_{1} \ldots x_{n}\right)^{m}+\left(1-y_{1}^{m}\right) \ldots\left(1-y_{n}^{m}\right)= \\
& \quad=\left(1-x_{i} \ldots x_{n-1}\left(1-y_{n}\right)\right)^{m}+\left(1-y_{1}^{m}\right) \ldots\left(1-y_{n-1}^{m}\right)\left(1-y_{n}^{m}\right) \geqslant \\
& \geqslant\left(1-x_{i} \ldots x_{n-i}+x_{1} \ldots x_{n-1} y_{n}\right)^{m}+\left(1-\left(1-x_{1} \ldots x_{n-1}\right)^{m}\right)\left(1-y_{n}^{m}\right)= \\
& =\left(a+(1-a) y_{n}\right)^{n}+\left(1-a^{m}\right)\left(1-y_{n}^{m}\right)=(a+-b-a b)^{m}+\left(1-a^{m}\right)\left(1-y^{m}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where we denote $a=1-x_{1} \ldots x_{n-1}$ and $b=y_{n}$. We will prove by induction on $m \in N$ that for any numbers $a, b \in[0 ; 1]$ the inequality

$$
(a+b-a b)^{m} \geqslant a^{m}+b^{m}-a^{m} b^{m}
$$

holds. For $m=1$, this inequality becomes an equality. Suppose the inequality is also true for the number $m-1$, i.e.,

$$
(a+b-a b)^{m-1} \geqslant a^{m-1}+b^{m-1}-a^{m-1} b^{m-1}
$$

Then (considering also that $a+b-a b \geqslant 0$) we obtain the validity of this inequality for the number $m$. Indeed,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& (a+b-a b)^{m}-a^{m}-b^{m}+a^{m} b^{m} \geqslant \\
& \geqslant\left(a^{m-1}+b^{m-1}-a^{m-1} b^{m-1}\right)(a+b-a b)-a^{m}-b^{m}+a^{m} b^{m}= \\
& =2 a^{m} b^{m}+a b^{m-1}+b a^{m-1}-a^{m} b^{m-1}-b^{m} a^{m-1}-a^{m} b-b^{m} a= \\
& =a^{m}\left(b^{m}-b^{m-1}\right)+a\left(b^{m-1}-b^{m}\right)+b^{m}\left(a^{m}-a^{m-1}\right)+b\left(a^{m-1}-a^{m}\right)= \\
& =\left(b^{m-1}-b^{m}\right)\left(a-a^{m}\right)+\left(a^{m-1}-a^{m}\right)\left(b-b^{m}\right) \geqslant 0
\end{aligned}
$$

since $a \geqslant a^{m-1} \geqslant a^{m}, b \geqslant b^{m-1} \geqslant b^{m}$. Thus, it is proven that for any number $m \in N$ the inequality holds, which can be rewritten as

$$
(a+b-a b)^{m}+\left(1-a^{m}\right)\left(1-b^{m}\right) \geqslant 1
$$

From this, according to the above notations, the required inequality in the problem is valid for the number $n$. The inductive step is completed. The statement is proven.
informal_statement:
7.18*. (NRA, 84). Prove that for any values of $m, n \in \mathbf{N}$ and any numbers $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}, y_{1}, \ldots, y_{n} \in[0 ; 1]$, satisfying the conditions $x_{i}+y_{i}=1$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$,

$$
\left(1-x_{1} \ldots x_{n}\right)^{m}+\left(1-y_{1}^{m}\right) \ldots\left(1-y_{n}^{m}\right) \geqslant 1
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Finset Real

/- 7.18*. (NRA, 84). Prove that for any values of $m, n \in \mathbf{N}$ and any numbers $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}, y_{1}, \ldots, y_{n} \in[0 ; 1]$, satisfying the conditions $x_{i}+y_{i}=1$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$,

$$
\left(1-x_{1} \ldots x_{n}\right)^{m}+\left(1-y_{1}^{m}\right) \ldots\left(1-y_{n}^{m}\right) \geqslant 1
$$ -/
theorem inequalities_121022 {m n : ℕ} (hn : 0 < n) (x y : ℕ → ℝ)
    (hx : ∀ i ∈ Icc 1 n, x i ∈ Set.Icc 0 1) (hy : ∀ i ∈ Icc 1 n, y i ∈ Set.Icc 0 1)
    (hxy : ∀ i ∈ Icc 1 n, x i + y i = 1) :
    (1 - ∏ i ∈ Icc 1 n, x i) ^ m + ∏ i ∈ Icc 1 n, (1 - (y i) ^ m) ≥ 1 := by

soln_description: The number $x=0$ cannot be a root of the equation $a x^{5}+b x^{4}+c=0$, because otherwise $c=0$, and the equation has no more than two distinct roots, which contradicts the condition. By dividing both sides of this equation by $x^{5}$, we get that $a+b / x^{\prime}+c / x^{5}=0$. Therefore, if $x_{1}, x_{2}$ and $x_{3}-$ are different roots of the equation $a x^{5}+b x^{4}+c=0$, then $1 / x_{1},{ }^{1} / x_{2}$ and ${ }^{1 / x_{3}}-$ are different roots of the equation $c x^{5}+b x+a=0$.
informal_statement:
Asahanov $H . X$.

It is known that the equation $a x^{5}+b x^{4}+c=0$ has three distinct roots. Prove that the equation $c x^{5}+b x+a=0$ also has three distinct roots.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Asahanov $H . X$.

It is known that the equation $a x^{5}+b x^{4}+c=0$ has three distinct roots. Prove that the equation $c x^{5}+b x+a=0$ also has three distinct roots. -/
theorem algebra_191283 (a b c : ℝ) (ha : a ≠ 0) (hroots : ∃ x y z, x ≠ y ∧ y ≠ z ∧ z ≠ x ∧
    a * x^5 + b * x^4 + c = 0 ∧ a * y^5 + b * y^4 + c = 0 ∧ a * z^5 + b * z^4 + c = 0) :
    ∃ x y z, x ≠ y ∧ y ≠ z ∧ z ≠ x ∧ c * x^5 + b * x + a = 0 ∧ c * y^5 + b * y + a = 0 ∧
    c * z^5 + b * z + a = 0 := by
